I think theres two things possible things going on here. 1. Absolutely an American diet can contribute to these inflammatory diseases. American foods are extremely packed with fat, sodium, sugar, chemicals, hormones. More so than most even developed countries in the world. This definitely leads to increased issues as we see with the diabetic and heart diseases epidemic we have here. Considering that many people with HS have found certain foods as triggers really proves how food can be a link to inflammatory symptoms. 2. People in Sri Lanka aren't reporting their symptoms or are being misdiagnosed. HS up until a few years ago was considered a rare disease. Mostly due to it going unreported because people are embarrassed about their symptoms and location of symptoms AND doctors were misdiagnosing the issue as just regular body acne or regular boils. Only in the past 5-10 years id say has this really come to light and more and more people are coming forward with symptoms and doctors are starting to become familiar with it. I mean they weren't even really studying or researching it when I started to learn about it. It was very much in its infancy here and is just starting to become a more known problem as the internet has helped people to connect with others like them and has allowed people to research diseases for themselves. I think its very likely that somewhere like Sri Lanka is still dealing with it going under the radar. If people don't come forward with their symptoms doctor's aren't aware of the condition and it goes undiagnosed. It is also possible that they simply have less cases because the diet isnt as processed. It could be a combination of the two. Its hard to say for sure.

I really doubt 10+ police officers are required to take down 1 person. Waste of money.

If they follow the standard DBT program its usually 1 group class a week thats about 2.5 hrs and a 1hr one on one session with a therapist. A DBT program is usually 6 months or longer. You spend about 4 weeks in each module. There are 4 modules I believe. With a new module usually comes new people. So youll have some people you see every week and some that may be new or are preparing to graduate. In my classes there typically isn't more than 8 in a group. You usually have 2 therapists leading the group through the lessons for the week. The class is very skilled based. Typically you'll start off with a Mindfulness exercise, then youll take up the homework for the week, and then you'll get into the lesson. The homework is based on the lesson you learned that week. It may mean implementing what you learned into everyday life and discussing how you did or filling out a worksheet from the book. The one on one will be more personal. You'll get to talk more about specific issues that are bothering you and they will help you navigate which skills would be helpful for those issues. Its very eye opening especially if you've never done DBT before. Its honestly just good skills to know for life in general. I think everyone should learn DBT skills regardless of if they are mentally ill lol but its especially eye opening for us because it really validates our thoughts and feelings and helps us to navigate our lives more effectively.

Definitely. Had cystic acne for over 10 years. Finally changed my diet and my acne is almost completely gone. For me its dairy, high sugar, and high fats but dairy is always a good place to start.

Especially depending on the cheese. Cheddar and mozzarella are absolute no's for me anymore but I can eat goats cheese and feta cheese with no issue. I can also have yogurt with no issue but straight up milk or ice cream is a no. Doesn't mean you'll have to cut out everything because I think you have to balance your goal with it being sustainable because its only going to help if you can sustain it so in my opinion I did just a few things at a time so I knew exactly what the culprit was. So if you think cheese is your issue maybe just cut out the main cheese you eat or the heavier cheeses first. That may be enough to get rid of the acne and you'll have less to cut out. Mind you it can take longer to figure out the trigger food this way but it can allow you to keep foods in your diet that you don't necessarily need to give up.

Pumpkin is really great for both constipation and diarrhea. Just helps digestion in general. My dog used to have this issues and pumpkin would help. So much so ive made it a regular item in her diet. I would try a teaspoon with her food see if it helps ( pure pureed pumpkin. Not pie filling pumpkin) . Oh and pumpkin will help with glands as well. It bulks up the poop. You can also get glandex which is a product sold for expressing glands. Its mostly made of pumpkin You may also want to look at her food. She could have allergies. My dog was allergic to certain proteins and she would never have a regular bowel. Always constipated or had diarrhea and has issues with glands too. I switched her food to a kangaroo diet and almost immediately her bowels became regular and all her other issues got better. I use Raynes low fat kangaroo. Its sold by vets. If it is allergies chicken is the most likely protein the dog is allergic to and chicken may be making it worse. I was advised the same thing and i didnt realize it was making it worse. Maybe try to change to a novel protein. Deer, fish, bison, duck, rabbit, kangaroo, are ones you can try. Chicken and beef are common for allergies. Unfortunetly my dog didn't agree with any commercial protein so i had to go with kangaroo. Allergies are common among dogs now, don't know if its likely to happen to such a young dog but thought id mention it since my dog had the same issues. Def go to vet though. With a puppy is could be a common problem im not sure as I never cared for a pup but keep food in the back of your mind because I find alot of vets don't acknowledge allergies as an issues very much. Out of like 6-8 vets my dog saw only one mentioned allergies to me.

I dont think its rude but with any behaviour you have to monitor whether the dogs are enjoying themselves or if its becoming a problem. Ive seen dogs that love to run up and down the fence with each other and i dont see an issue with it but if your dog is just barking and the other dog seems worked up or stress then yeah id call my dog back. To be honest the way you explain it sounds like the guy may have been annoyed at his own dogs. Perhaps he wasnt happy with their behaviour. Maybe it wasnt actually directed towards your dog. I wasnt there though i dont know but if both dogs seemed relaxed I really dont see an issue with letting them interact through a fence.

I have heard this as well from a lot of trainers. Ultimately its your call. I still like to socialize my dog but I go when the park is very quite and we'll see maybe 1 or 2 dogs there. I find when shes had no interactions with dogs shes more reactive to them on walks but that's my personal experience. From what ive been told most adult dogs just need good exercise and the dog park can cause more issues than its worth. Add on top of that your fear of an attack and a higher possibility of an attack from a pitbull OR another dog. I would say it would benefit you to go elsewhere, visit at a quieter time, or simply change what you do to exercise your dog.

Pitbulls absolutely are more likely to attack TO KILL than other breeds and ignoring that fact is the reason there are so many attacks. If you own a weapon you need to know how to handle it properly and people are getting pitbulls without knowing anything about them and not acknowledging the FACT many of them have a high prey drive. It takes very specific training to safely own a pitbull and the best owners are those that acknowledge the increased risk and handle it accordingly.

These type of people are exactly why pitbull attacks keep happening. They pretend the prey drive doesn't exist and dont train them accordingly. Its really irresponsible to underestimate this breed and does a disservice to them and to other dogs that may become a victim because of an ignorant owner.

It makes sense that this argument got out of hand because if she also has BPD she definitely felt attacked. To be honest neither of you were being skillful in this moment. DBT is meant to help you. Not to help the other person. In this situation it doesnt matter whos right or whos wrong. The situation escalated and once it escalates no one is being skillful. If your going by DBT skills you would have removed yourself from the situation to help you. Not to help her. You remove yourself so you dont say anything you dont want to and you dont get into a worse situation. Your not removing yourself for her your removing yourself for you. You are the only person you can control so you should focus on that. For this specific situation there are skills in interpersonal effectiveness that would have made this conversation more effect. Saying something sternly and saying things like ive told you 100 times will sound attacking to alot of people. Your placing the blame on someone instead of trying to resolve the issues with communication. In the interpersonal effectiveness chapter there is a script you can use for situations where you want someone to do something. Its the DEARMAN skill. This should be done at a time when both of you are in a neutral state. This script will help you form your thoughts in such a way that you will ask instead of demand something from someone. It will allow you two to talk about the situation and come to a resolution without anyone feeling like they were right or wrong because it really doesn't matter. What matters the goal. That the door gets shut. You also have to be open to compromise and to accepting that they may not do what you want. I would strongly suggest looking up this skill. This is the appropriate skill to use for this situation.

Sure. Crying can be a form of relief. Also alot of people may feel alot of ways after an event like that. Guilt, remorse, frustration, sadness. I would focus on how to avoid yelling and letting anger take over. This will help you not have this after effect of sadness. Lots of DBT skills to help you deal effectively with these emotions.

You are not going to get the response you want if you have a "you vs her" outlook on it. #8203; gt;Shes always the one to yell. Well that's her issue, isn't it? She obviously doesn't have the skills necessary to approach things in a skillful manner. So you can either continue to blame her and nothing get accomplished but a ruined relationship or you can anticipate that she is sensitive, doesn't have the skills to keep her temper in check, and approach it in a different manner. Which if you know DBT as well as you say you do would be the DEARMAN approach. #8203; gt;She clearly has an anger problem (I dont. I have more of a sad response, in private). Everyone experiences BPD differently. Hers is anger and to attack. Yours may be sadness and to retreat. They are both symptoms of BPD and neither is better than another its just different. A little empathy could go along way here. You are both struggling with intense emotions. I know it feels like "you're doing all the work" but that's what DBT is. It's skills you use to make the situation better. You can't change anyone's behavior or outlook but your own. If you show some compassion perhaps she would respond to that vs feeling attacked. #8203; gt;So my thing is why should I always be the one to leave the room when she yells? #8203; You don't have to leave the room if she yells. There are plenty of ways to deescalate a situation without leaving the room but one option is to step away because once people start yelling at each other its no longer an effective situation and there is no point to it. You don't have to walk off like your "running scared". You could simply say something like " We are obviously both getting upset about this conversation maybe we should come back to it when we both cool down a bit". Again, it's to serve you not her. Did you like the way you felt after having that argument with her? I don't think you did considering you came on reddit to talk about it. Maybe if you had taken a different approach you would have felt better about the interaction. Thats the point of using DBT skills, its so at the end of the day you can feel good about the way you acted regardless of how the other person decides to act. #8203; gt;She should be doing her own DBT and leaving the area when she feels upset. #8203; You can't control how others act. You can only control yourself. Whether she is acting in a way you would doesn't matter because it's not in your control. It would be nice if everyone thought the way we thought but it just doesn't happen like that. You don't know what kind of vulnerabilities shes bringing into this conversation so who's to say how she should react to it. If you have the control to be able to leave a situation then that's what you should focus on because at the end of the day that's all you can do. You can shoulda, woulda, coulda, her all you want but it will never change the fact that you can't control what she does regardless of if its right or wrong. #8203; gt;That was my point that I cant be the one to run away everytime she yells. #8203; It's not running away. Its removing yourself from a situation that isn't serving YOU anymore. Like I said above. You don't have to "runaway" you could simply point out the obvious. "This conversation isn't effective right now because we are both upset and I think we should pick it up later". That's DBT. You want to be skillful. That's what being skillful is. #8203; gt;Because that just reinforces the idea that I'm wrong when I'm not wrong or right I just want the door shut #8203; It doesn't reinforce anything. It just tells her you see the conversation isn't working right now and you want to pick it up later. Its pretty straight forward and even if she takes it as "Ha, she's wrong" who cares. That's her thought that's not fact and when you do come back to the conversation at another time when you both are able to effectively talk, You will be able to explain what you want and she will actually be able to hear you. You are making an assumption that shes going to think because you left you are wrong but that's your assumption. You don't know that's what she's thinking and leaving an escalating situation never means you are wrong. It means you have the ability to see when a conversation is no longer effective and do what needs to be done to get it back on track. Again this is DBT. #8203; gt;No blame, no tricks and no bs. Just shut the freaking door #8203; Yes, This conversation is possible but there is a lot of factors that contribute to someone's interpretation of what you are saying. Tone, body language, use of words, etc., If you came with a "Stern" tone, an aggressive body language, and blaming words of course shes going to get defensive. Instead of making it a conversation you made it an order and I am sure she feels just as "right" to have the door open as you do to have the door closed. She obviously has her reasons and she feels she is not being heard. This has nothing to do with whether your request was valid or not but when having a conversation like this with someone it does pay to listen to what they have to say, to ask rather than demand, and be willing to find a compromise if possible. You know you are dealing with someone with BPD and have done DBT so you are aware of how these things can make a big difference in how a conversation is interpreted. I understand the frustration of feeling like you have to do all the work but that is life, unfortunately. We can't control others and if we want to live this life a little more peacefully it is up to us to do the work and be skillful. Being skillful doesn't mean you are wrong. Being skillful allows you to live a better life. It benefits you. You should want to be skillful to make your life easier.

**DEARMAN:** #8203; * **Describe** the current situation (if necessary). Stick to the facts. Tell the person exactly what you are reacting to. I want to talk to you about the door. Leaving the door open allows mosquitos to come in that are biting me. #8203; * **Express** your feelings and opinions about the situation. Don #8217;t assume that the other person knows how you feel. Use "I" statements I am feeling a little frustrated because I have asked for the door to be closed before. I am upset that I am getting bite by mosquitoes and am afraid it may affect my ability to do training. #8203; * **Assert** yourself by asking for what you want or saying no clearly. Do not assume that others will figure out what you want. Remember that others cannot read your mind. I would really like it if we could keep the door closed from now on #8203; * **Reinforce** (reward) the person ahead of time (so to speak) by explaining positive effects of getting what you want or need. If necessary, also clarify the negative consequences of not getting what you want or need. If you are able to do this I feel like it will help our relationship. I would really appreciate you doing this for me so I don't get bite by mosquitos anymore. I am worried if this keeps happening I will grow more resentful and our relationship will suffer. #8203; * **Mindful** Keep your focus on your goals. Maintain your position. Don #8217;t be distracted. Don #8217;t get off the topic. #8220;Broken record #8221;: Keep asking, saying no, or expressing your opinion over and over and over. Just keep replaying the same thing again and again. Ignore attacks: If another person attacks, threatens, or tries to change the subject, ignore the threats, comments, or attempts to divert you. Do not respond to attacks. Ignore distractions. Just keep making your point. I would just really appreciate it if we could keep the door close. #8203; * **Appear** confident, effective, and competent. Use a confident voice tone and physical manner; make good eye contact. No stammering, whispering, staring at the floor, retreating. #8203; * **Negotiate** Be willing to give to get. Offer and ask for other solutions to the problem. Reduce your request. Say no, but offer to do Something else or to solve the problem another way. Focus on what will work. Validate the other person's feelings. I understand that you want to keep the door open as you think it's too hot in there. I would really prefer it if we keep it closed so I don't get bite by mosquitos. What you do think we can do about this? OR Compromise: If it helps I am willing to make a compromise, maybe we can put a fan in there to keep it cooler? What do you think? OR I would like to solve this problem. We both live here and it's important we are both heard. Do you have any other solutions? #8203; **GIVE** * **Gentle,** Don #8217;t attack, threaten or express judgment during your interactions. Accept the occasional #8220;no #8221; for your requests. * **Interested,** Show interest by listening to the other person without interrupting. * **Validate.** Be outwardly validating to the other person #8217;s thoughts and feelings. Acknowledge their feelings, recognize when your requests are demanding, and respect their opinions. * **Easy ,**Have an easy attitude. Try to smile and act lighthearted. FAST * **Fair,** Be fair. Not only to others, but also to yourself. * **Apologies,** Don #8217;t apologize unless it #8217;s warranted. Don #8217;t apologize for making a request, having an opinion, or disagreeing. * **Stick to Values,** Don #8217;t compromise your values just to be liked or to get what you want. Stand up for what you believe in. * **Truthful ,** Avoid dishonesty such as exaggeration, acting helpless as a form of manipulation, or outright lying.

I think it depends of course. Canadians are known as big beer drinkers but I think that's been shifting a bit. I think the most popular types of beers here are pale lagers. Either the massed produced canadian or american brands like Molson, Coors, Budweiser, etc. In the last few years we've seen a spike in local/craft beers. People like the idea of supporting local beer and have been shifting to more British Columbia, Alberta and Ontario Beers. Ciders have also become very popular in the last few years. International ciders like strongbow are popular but like beers more and more locals ciders are popping up and becoming prefered. Wine has definitely become a staple especially for women but even men. I feel like if people are "partying" they'll stick to a white wine but lots of people have a glass of wine for any social event really, even a glass after work lol. I don't see preferences for brands of wines to be honest. Not with my age group anyways which is 25-35. I think with wine it mostly comes down to price and preference. As for liquor id say its probably pretty similar as with the USA. Most popular liquors here are vodka, rum, and rye (whisky).

I used to serve beer at the rogers arena in Vancouver for hockey games. I would say the most common was Coors, Canadian, and Budweiser as they are the cheapest. Beer at hockey games go for like $18 bucks a pop. Its ridiculous really. Other commons ones were Heineken for premium and Rickards does well too. Shocktop was a new one we had on tap and and it did quite well during the season. For coolers we do a lot of mikes hard lemonade and for ciders we do alot of the okanagan ciders and batch 1904. Wine at hockey games certainly isn't as popular as its more expensive and isn't really a hockey game type of drink. Hard liquors aren't as popular either purely because they are too expensive at games. The beer stands are always the busiest. It depends what arena your at though. Most arenas have contracts with companies so you may only be able to get molson products, etc. But yeah for most canadians at a hockey game is comes down to affordability and a standard draft beer is going to give you more bang for your buck.

Premium in Canada usually refers to international beers that are higher in price. Premium can also refer to beers that have high alcohol content. Heineken, Stella Artois, Guinness are common premium beers. People may be more inclined to get a premium beer when at dinner but I find the average canadian wont opt for premium if they are at an event or going to a party as its not as cost effective. Some people may call craft beer premium as the price is higher but alot of places will make the distinction of domestic, premium, and craft beer. "Cheap" beer is domestic and consists of the major brand beers.

No. This area is known as the triangle of death for a good reason. There are alot if blood vessels in this area that lead to the eyes and brain. If you pop one and it gets infected you could get a serious infection that could lead to blindness, even death. There was a case not that long ago of a girl who popped a pimple on her face and it immediately started swelling. Turned out to be cellulitis and she was at risk of going blind. Not worth it. I would make sure you cleanse morning and night and use salicylic acid on your face to help dry out the spots and help them heal. Also use a lightweight oil free free moisturizer like complex 15 to help moisturize the skin so the salicylic acid doesn't strip.

Look up hidradenitis suppurativa. It's a condition that seems like acne at first but its actually more like boils. It typically starts off as "butt acne" when you are younger and can progress to worse outbreaks. Its an inflammatory condition that is typically genetic. I have this condition and was told I had body acne for years until I finally found a dermatologist that told me about HS. It has nothing to do with sweating, or dirt, etc. It's essentially an autoimmune disorder. Starts off usually on the bum,thighs,and groin but can progress to under the breasts, armpits, and stomach. A lot of people find relieve with diet changes as many foods are inflammatory and can worsen the the condition. Smoking and weight gain can also worsen the condition. Usually shows up around puberty but may not show up till early 20's. If this is the case you probably have stage 1. There are hidradentitis subreddits that have a lot of information if you think this condition fits the bill. There really is no cure except some topicals and trying to find your triggers. Obviously I cant see what your spots look like but with puss and the area thats affected its possible this is what you are actually experiencing. HS was once considered a rare disease but with more people using the internet and more doctors becoming aware they are realising its more common then they thought. If it is simply acne a body wash with salicylic acid or an antifungal like tea tree could help. I would also change to a scent free laundry detergent in case you have a sensitivity. Try to wear cotton clothing and underwear to let the area breathe and moisture wicking fabric when working out.

Yeah I mean for me it's kind of standard bad food Unfortunately lol. I cant eat ANYTHING fried for starters. So completely avoid that. For sugar again its stuff with very high sugar so milk chocolate, pastries, cakes, etc. And for dairy its high lactose stuff so milk,ice cream, cheddar cheese, mozzarella cheese. These are the major things I had to cut out Then it gets kind of complicated lol because it seems in moderation I can eat other fatty things like butter or sauces but give me too fatty of a steak and i break out. So I basically just have to limit the higher fat foods. I buy all lean meat now to help reduce. Same for sugar. I can eat dark chocolate without much issue but if i eat too much or eat it a few days in a row my skins done. For sugary stuff i basically cant eat anything commercially. The milk chocolate kills me. I tend to do better if I buy dark chocolate stuff from the health food section. Other then that I have tried not to cut too many things out of my diet because I want it to be sustainable. So I still eat fruits, and whole wheat bread/pastas and my acne has still reduced greatly. I would say its 90% gone at this point. in order to get to 100% I may have to start looking at removing wheat but im not ready to do that yet lol because im still seeing improvement. I do keep to only whole wheat/grain items and when i can buy brown rice pastas which seem to do better with my digestion and have less sugars. So basically removing the really inflammatory foods and keep the others in moderation.

Bha or ahas toners are good for texture. I had an isssued with textured skin for so long and these didnt work for me though. The only product that worked and made my face feel like a baby again was Herbivores Blue Tansy mask. Its sold at sephora and is stupid expensive but it was honestly like magic. It was on for 20 minutes and i had new skin. Something to invest in if you are really getting frustrated. Ive done dermaplaning at home as well which did help with some texture but the blue tansy really gave me a fresh start again.

Alot of the time simpler is better. I would def add a moisturizer and a mineral SPF. AM -Cerave Cleasner -Toner- optional (niacinamide is good for acne prone skin, or vit C oil is good for acne scarring and skin inflammation) -Moisturizer -SPF PM -Cerave cleanser -Epiduo -Moisturizer. Hyaluronic acid would typically go before your moisturizer as it pulls moisture. However if the epiduo is a gel this may affect the order in which you should use it. I would check with your derm or simply get a moisturizer that contains Hyaluronic acid. If you want to help your acne get a mineral sunscreen specifically for acne prone skin. Ppl with acne avoid sunscreen due to fear it will clog pores but sun damage inflames acne, dries out skin which causes your skin to produce more oil, not to mention it causes wrinkles. As long as you do a good cleanse at the end of the day an SPF will do more good than harm. Same as moisturizers. Dry skin will produce more oil and by not using a moisturizer you could be inadvertently causing your skin to produce more. Even if your skin is oily it needs hydration. The ones ive found best for acne is complex 15 (sold on amazon) extremely lightweight very good for day wear. First aid beauty ultra repair cream ( sold at sephora). Thicker formula but does not clog pores. Great for night time. There is a guy called Hyram on youtube. His videos are very educational and ive learned alot from him. Theres also a dermatologist called Dr. Dray that has good insight as well as Cassandra Bankson. Hyram and Cassandra both had acne and are skin car specialists.

Totally get it. I actually thought i would never get rid of my texture because nothing worked i just figured I did the damage and now its permanent lol. I literally jumped for joy after using the blue tansy mask i just couldn't believe the difference it made i hadnt felt my skin feel like that in years. It really worked for me, obviously its not a guarantee but based on others ratings and experience it sounds like others have similar experiences. I definitely think it was worth the money and you use surprisingly little so it lasts longer than it seems it will.

You are better off getting a therapist tbh. Its not the actual food thats the issue is the reason why we are going to the food. There is kind of 2 ways i did it. First was to take out common triggers 1 at a time for 2-3 weeks and monitor if I see any difference. Dairy, high fat foods, and high sugar foods are most common. Maybe start with the one in your diet that you think may be most problematic. For me it was high fat food. After a few weeks i notice it did make a difference but was still getting some flares so I moved to high sugar foods. That helps as well and then I moved on to high dairy foods as i was still having some issues. Once I had been a few months with little flares I started introducing things here and there and really see what was a major trigger and what could be eaten in moderation. Now that i have major triggers worked out i record everything I eat to catch the ones i haven't been able to. Its a process. I started oct 2019. My HS went from level 3 to 1, cystic acne is almost all gone, IBS is much better, and acid reflux is rare but even 10 months later i still get issues here and there where i dont know what caused it which is why writing down everything is giving me a much clearer picture but I think a good place is to pick 1 major inflammatory food first because the thing is its not going to help if your diet becomes unsustainable. If yoy remove everything with fat,sugar, and dairy. Your down to salads everyday lol. Its important to find a balance so my goal was to try to reduce as little as possible so i can stick to it.

General practitioners aren't great with psychological issues. Its not their specialty. They tend to see things in very general terms so you'll likey get general treatment like an antidepressant, appetite suppressant, or just a diet plan. What you need is a psychological assessment by a psychiatrist so they can assess the eating disorder properly and any other issues you may be dealing with. Through the psychiatrist you be referred into specialized programs that will actual address the binge eating not just the symptoms. Now I am not in the UK i am in Canada but if your system is similar to ours i would find a hospital or clinic that has eating disorder programs and request specifically to your doctor that you want to get sent for an assessment to that center. Most places you do need a doctors referral so a lot of the time you'll have to be very straight forward with your request as to what you want from your doctor. I would even go online print out the referral form and bring it to my doctor so all they had to do was sign and send lol. Not every doctor will do what you want and will try to give you general treatment but you need to keep pushing for this specialized treatment because it's really what works.

Like everyone else said food testing isnt accurate. My dog had bad allergies to almost all protein. She went on that Hills diet as well and it did reduce alot of her symptoms but I too was not a fan of the nutritional value and she still didn't seem 100%. Finally i went with my gut and changed her to Raynes Low Fat Kangaroo Dry food and it was like night and day. Within a few weeks all of her allergy symptoms were gone. She looked brighter and healthier than ever. Bowels normalized, skin cleared up, hair grew back, she was softer, thicker. It was fantastic. She been on it now over a year and we've had no issues. Other than the price lol. It is vet exclusive here and has a had a lot of increases in price because of the Australia wildfires BUT the monthly bill for the food is still far less than the constant vet visits for her allergy symptoms and im happy to see her not having to go through all the symptoms anymore.

Yeah from like a university or something which is really unnecessary to be honest. No one should pay more than $350 for a TELF certification if they are planning abroad teaching or remote teaching. The ones in canada are a straight up rip off. Your better off with an online program which many are accredited as well. The only way a TELF or TESOL course through a university or other overly priced place like oxford education would be a benefit is if you have a bachelors degree and are planning to work domestically with esl students or are trying to work for government run schools in other countries. Like I said ...if you want to work for government run schools, domestic, or places that require a bachelor's you'll do better with a program. If you are looking to do remote work or work in places with less requirements like South America a TELF is typically all that's required and some may require a bachelors in any subject as well.

Yeup. Ive been in recovery 10 months and still have digestive issues. I think it can take a really long time for your gut to balance itself out again. Theres a lot of damage being done there while in the binge /restrict cycle. Things ive found that help is reducing inflammatory foods. Dairy, high sugar content, and high fat foods are worst for me. These are very inflammatory to the system and can increase problems. Since we have binge eating disorder we need to be careful not to restrict for the wrong reasons. Ive found when I am removing foods from my diet for health reasons I have no urges to binge. Its only when the focus is on weightloss/self image that restricting leads to binging. In order to ensure your successful I would do it slowly to see what some of your triggers for symptoms are. Pick 1 of the most inflammatory foods in your diet and remove it for a few weeks. Monitor symptoms. If they improve you know its probably is link. If its improved a little you know you may need to remove something else. If it doesn't do anything move on to something new. Once I found my triggers I do find if I eat them i have a WAY bigger reaction than i did before. Whether its because im just not used to it anymore or removing it makes me more sensitive you have to be aware that if a food is a trigger youll have to keep it out of your diet for a while. Your gut needs quite a long time to heal. Drink lots of water as it helps with digestion. Exercise helps with digestion as well. Even a 20 minute walk a day will help massage the intestine. Try to eat a balance diet with lots of vitamins and fibre. Try to stay away from white processed foods. Whole wheat/grains are good for digestion. Almost everything comes in whole wheat options now. Try to stay seated upright 1-2 hours after eating. Lying down could have an effect on the acid in your stomach. Writing down what you eat and your symptoms can help you see patterns. Again be careful with this because it could trigger your eating disorder but I find if I only write the food and symptoms and not calorie etc it doesnt trigger me as much. Tums can help alot if you feel indigestion starting. Take a tums to reduce that acid. If you find your taking tums everyday for weeks you should go visit a doctor. You may need something more powerful to help your stomach recover. It sounds like IBS to me which can improve but a change in diet may be required to reduced trigger foods.

Oh tomatoes are very inflammatory. Anything from the nightshade family. Potatoes, tomatoes, peppers, eggplant etc. Alot of people with inflammation find issues with these vegetables tomatoes in particular is an issue. I myself don't seem to have issues but Ive seen alot of people say tomatoes are a real trigger for them. So dairy and tomato sauce sounds like an inflammatory nightmare lol. Since you already have a feeling dairy is an issue id start there. Once its been removed for a bit you can better asses whether its the dairy or tomatoes that cause issues. Ill also say not all dairy is the same. Milk, creme,heavier cheese like mozzarella and cheddar seem to be much more inflammatory than things like yogurt, goats cheese, feta cheese. I say this because again i dont think you necessarily need to remove it all maybe just remove the higher fat, higher lactose items. See if that makes a difference before you completely wipe out dairy. Just a suggestion as I can still eat thing with dairy just not the heavier stuff.

Its dairy so it's a big trigger if your acne is sensitive to dairy. A lot of people's acne is triggered by dairy so this is a likely link. Only way to really know is to cut it out and monitor your outbreaks.
Medication can be an aid but you really should be in some sort of therapy or program if you are not already. Medication doesnt get to the root of the problem which 9/10 times is psychological.

BED isnt really an issue of cravings. Its an issue of coping. Especially if you have MDD you likely just dont have effective coping strategies so you use food. BED is 9/10 times a psychological issue so though meds may help therapy/ED programs are whats going to address the root problem. Once youve address those issues you'll notice craving reducing because you have skills to properly cope. You may not realize you use food to cope but maybe you should start paying attention to what you feel when you binge. Most success stories you see on here start with a change in perspective or therapy. BED is a mental illness and should be treated as such. I strongly recommend finding a program or therapist that works with ED or in CBT or DBT therapy. This will address why you binge so you can get control of it. Cravings are a symptom of binge eating disorder. It doesnt cure you of it.

This is so dangerous lol. Which you obviously know but for those of you who are going to try this there is always a chance it could lead to an accident. Burns being the most obvious. If you burn the flare its more likely to get infected and HS can cause staph and sepsis easily which can be deadly. Then theres the chance you may just burn yourself in general. Also wrapping stuff around an iron is a fire hazard. It could burn, melt, etc. If heat is something that you think will help I think there are safer options. Damp cloth with hot water, hot water bottle, a heating mat, heated blanket, hot/cold pack, hot bean bag compress, general warm compresses. I would try these before jumping to a 400 #176; iron. It's not a very smart idea. Sorry to say. I think its dangerous to suggest it before trying other things that create heat safely.

Yes I do. I have done the full DBT program twice. The first time it helped for a while but I ended up in a pretty bad place again after about 6 months. This last time It pulled me out if depression completely and im basically in remission. Depending on your life circumstances, life stressors, who your therapists are, etc I think it can have different outcomes BUT even if it may not cure you youll learn very valuable lessons and get some insight into why you do the things you do which is very validating and can help change your perspective on a lot of things. It really is a necessary treatment for BPD. Its so specific to us you just cant get that from regular therapy or medication. There are a lot of skills required to help reduce symptoms and dbt will teach you those. I am very lucky i live in canada so it was free for me both times. It may be worth it to see if there are any programs that are covered by your government or perhaps insurance. Any grants or other programs available maybe for low income individuals. I think its worth it but I dont know if I could afford that much either. I think its worth it to have a good research and make sure you exhaust the free options first but if this is the only option its a good investment for the future. I really don't know how someone with BPD finds long term recovery without DBT. Thats just my opinion.

Absolutely but as a health care professional ive seen many people trying to "hack" this kind of stuff and they end up in our clinic or the hospital. The main point here is heat helped. So I offered plenty of safer options to produce heat than to potentially make a bad situation worse by causing another injury, fire, or infection. People read this and are looking for anything that will bring them relief and they are not thinking about the potential consequences of using a dangerous item on your skin like an iron. Trust me. I was in grade 8 in history class. We were doing in class work or reading or something. All of a sudden the teacher told us all to "SHHHHH!!" And she turned on a radio we had in class. We just all sat there in silence while she listened in clear terror. We we're kind of confused at first. It was so weird for a teacher to act like that. We started to understand that something bad was happening but didnt quite understand the severity of it as clearly our teacher did. I think most of us were a little scared, worried, but mostly confused. When we got home and the videos of the towers were on the news thats when it sunk in what we were really listening to. It was a serious moment in history. Ill never forget it because Ill never forget how human my teacher seemed at that moment. As a child I found it terrifying to see an adult so terrified.

I was in Canada too but they didnt lock down our school. I do remember living in fear for months after though because we lived near a nuclear powerplant and everyone was speculating if they were going to attack Canada it could very well be a nuclear power plant. Duno how accurate that was but everytime a plane flew over we were terrified.

Ive had a fever and flu symptoms just from a bad HS flare. Yeah it might be cute but its cutting into your sleep and your sleep is important. I would try a dog bed in your room as well like others have said. If that doesn't work i would ignore her. If the pattern is consistently just that she wants to go on the couch then you know she doesnt have to pee so you shouldn't even get outta bed anymore when she barks. When she barks tell her no and tell her to go to bed or to go lie down. This is why is good to have a dog bed that is her bed. Its good to have a place you can tell her to go so she gets the cue to stop what shes doing and go to her space. Seriously though it may be cute now but it wont be cute if you have something important the next day and shes waking you out of important sleep to make you sleep on a couch where you'll be less rested. Everytime you oblige her your reinforcing the behaviour and she'll keep going/ it may lead to more demanding behaviour in the future. I think letting some things fly because your not super strict is fine but its not appropriate for a dog to be waking you out of your sleep. Sleep is the most important thing for us to function. In this case you need to put yourself first. Edit. Sorry i see now this is posted as fluff. Thought it was an advice piece. Feel free to ignore my advice, to each their own if your fine with it.

I agree that it would be beneficial to have a program that is specifically targeted for ODSP. Like the summer jobs program for students but there may be options you haven't looked into. ODSP does have employment supports. Your worker can set you up with a community counsellor that can help you find work, keep work, or help you increase your skills. This is probably your best option as its specifically for ppl on ODSP. I am currently working with an ODSP approved provider for career counselling and its helping me to figure out what i want to do / what I need to do to do it. Youre young so there are still a lot of options for you to expand your skills. If you have disability there are options for grants and bursaries to cover costs of courses/programs if that's what you feel you need. These programs can really help you get on track to a better future. If you have tried that the YMCA also has a program that pays employers the training costs associated with a new hire. Which means employers have an incentive to hire from YMCA. The YMCA provides all kinds of employment services. They can help you set up your resume, they have workshops, will help you apply for jobs that are included in that program. Through the YMCA you may not have as much competition and employers are looking to benefit from the money they offer. There are usually other local programs that work with employers too to help aid ppl in finding work. I know where I live there is a program through our municipal government that also offers incentives to employers and will help connect you with those employers. [ODSP employment support providers](https://www.mcss.gov.on.ca/en/mcss/programs/social/odsp/employment_support/EmploymentServiceProviders.aspx) [YMCA employment services canada](https://www.ymca.ca/What-We-Offer/Employment-Services)
Dickhead

You should seek mental health care. You are obviously depressed and using binge eating as a form of self harm. I did this too. I got proper mental health care and have found recovery but even though im better ive done permanent damage to my body by trying to use food to kill myself. You have the chance for a life with recovery but it will be a tough one if you go through this for too long. You need to be your own advocate. Find help. Its what can get you through this. 1. Mental health assessment - Get proper diagnoses 2. With a proper diagnoses you are able to get into proper programs 2. Program/ therapy based around DBT, CBT, or eating disorder specific is best.

When you have an eating disorder restriction feeds it. I know loosing weight is crucial for your health but you'll never loose weight long term if you have an active eating disorder because diets feed the eating disorder and make it worse. You need to put the diet aside for now and focus on your mental health. You need therapy or a program. CBT, DBT, or ED specific therapy is best. When you get control of the root of the eating disorder everything will fall into place. Ive lost 75 pounds since November without diet or exercise. I did it by working on my mental health and getting my binge eating under control. I only got my binge eating under control by working on my mental health and figuring out the connection. You are not in the same category of people who just need will power to loose weight. No, you need mental health help and its astonishing that these bariatric doctors still cant see an eating disorder when its slapping them in the face. Ive been there. I know the struggle. I promise you the diet is doing more harm than good and you need to push to see a real mental health professional.
Are you on the diet because you had the surgery or you are going to have the surgery?

I was misdiagnosed as bipolar 1 and 2 lol. I finally got a proper diagnoses of BPD. Not saying thats your case but in regards to the eating disorder the BPD treatment helped WAY more than anything I got when they thought I was bipolar. Bipolar therapy usually focuses around CBT therapy IF your therapist uses a program based therapy at all. BPD uses DBT. DBT has helped immensely with not just my disorder but my ED. DBT focuses on coping skills. BED really comes down to a lack of coping skills. I would suggest you talk to your therapist about this. Either ask if an ED specific program is available or if she is familiar with DBT skills and could walk you through some. Theres also lots of websites and books/workbooks on it. I think theyve even started developing ED programs with DBT because its so successful but nothing worked for me until I did this program.

It's commonly known to start at age 11+ but that's because puberty is more likely to start at 11+. I started puberty at 9 years old so it's not out of the realm of possibility. The area in which its happening and the look of the flare/the scars it leaves are the most identifiable thing about the condition. You'll get a better idea if you look it up. I would look up stage 1 photos as stage 2-3 can get pretty graphic.

WRITING.TITLE: Thought I was in a remission... Doesn't take much to get me out
WRITING.TEXT: Ive been doing quite well with BPD lately. After hitting rock bottom i moved back home and started an intensive BPD program. The combination of the program, not working, and not having a lot of bills to keep up with allowed me to focus soley on my mental health and it worked. I finished the whole program and while doing the last assessment my symptoms had gone down so much they weren't even readable as bpd anymore. I knew it wouldn't stay like that forever but am so surprised how easy it is to come back. I've been doing nothing for the last 10 months but doing mental health programs. The last 2 weeks have been busier. I got a few interviews for jobs, started training for a volunteer position, and have been taking some career workshops. 3 things that dont even take up my whole day and i am overwhelmed already. My irritability is coming back, im feeling sad, and I just had my first episode of feeling out of control in a long time. It just really feeds into my belief that Ill never be able to handle anything and this cycle will go on and on. I hate this fucking illness. I really do. And question my ability to live a "normal" life. Even though I dont want to I am going to finish this vent off with giving myself credit because i know thats what im supposed to do if im being "skillful" lol 1. I was able to acknowledge that my emotions we're getting hot and removed myself from others to go to my room 2. I was able to identify what I was feeling. Sad/Scared 3. I was able to list off the thoughts that were causing these feelings ; i get overwhelmed too easy, the pattern is starting again, ill never be normal, I'm going to become mean again, I'm letting my dog down ( havent taken her on big walks this week), Im going to be stuck like this forever. 4. Thanks for listening. Just venting but maybe someone will relate lol.

Personally I found AIP diet way too restrictive. I get thats the point but its not going to help if its not sustainable. After trying AIP and failing because I started to have an aversion to meat i took the opposite approach lol. Instead of removing everything inflammatory and then adding it back in slowly. I removed 1 inflammatory item at a time and watched for symptom relief. They both take a long time but at least my method didn't make me hate my life lol. I looked at the most inflammatory kinds of foods in my diet. Sugar, fat, dairy and decided which one was most prevalent . I started with high fat foods and decided to cut them out for a few weeks. I did notice a reduction so I continued and added high sugar foods for a few weeks. That also helped a lot so i kept that going a few months after that I slowly tried to see what i could reintroduce and what i couldnt. My HS reduced but i was still had some flares so i removed high dairy food as well. I went like that for a few months. By 8 months i figured out what diary, fat, and sugar foods i could tolerate and couldn't. My HS reduced from stage 3 to 1. Ill get an odd one here and there so now I write down every food i eat to try to figure out what other foods may be a trigger it that haven't realized but I am FAR better off now than i was and typically dont experience anything too bad unless i eat something i know i shouldnt. I just found this was a more sustainable way to do it and the easiest to way to ease myself in. Even though AIP and all that is for our health its still part of this diet culture where we really see it as all or nothing. I think that way of eating can be detrimental to our mental health AND our gut health so that's why i decided to take a more gradual approach. Alot of ppl don't get far enough through AIP to really understand what their triggers are. AIP could take 3 months to over a year. Its a long long commitment and ppl put in alot of hours to ultimately "fail" . I think its important to try to minimize the amount of food you are removing from your diet so you can eat a moderate balanced diet which is what will be required for longterm success. This is of course my opinion.

I used to work at an optometrists office that also sold glasses. Odsp was always complicated to deal with. People often were dissapointed with what they could actually get covered by odsp it usually wasnt a lot. Most people couldn't get frames they liked they had to get the least expensive frames and just kind of deal with what those were. The doctor has to send the info to odsp. If they told you they accept odsp they've done it many times b4 and shouldnt be an issue.

A diet will never be the answer to recovery. Doesn't matter what the diet is. Diets = increase in symptoms. Ive lost 75 pounds in 10 months and i did it by STOPPING dieting, and stopping trying to loose weight. Its not bullshit. There is a reason so many ppl on here talk about not restricting. You will loose weight naturally when you stop dieting and focus on your mental health instead. Recovery from BED will bring better weight loss results then any diet you could ever try. Because recovering from BED can be long term, sustainable weight loss. Not just a short term fix. Sorry to say but keto will do nothing but continue the cycle. BED is a mental illness for a reason. Its a psychological issue that manifests as food binging. It's not actually about the type of food you eat. It has nothing to do with will power, or carbs, or calories. It has everything to do with figuring out why you are binging, associating emotions to the binge urges, learning coping skills for those emotions, and combating self image issues. Food is just a tool we use to cope with all these things we don't have proper skills for/understanding of.

Its not about controlling the desire to eat its about learning to cope with the feelings that give you that desire to eat. You are using food as a coping mechanism because you don't have coping skills for sadness, anger, etc. Eating disorders are psychological. Learn how to identify your emotions and how to effectively deal with them and your binging urges will naturally decrease and you will be able to find recovery. Shift the focus from food intake to improving mental health. That's the way to recovery. Therapy, especially CBT, DBT, or ED specific. If you cant afford or cant get it covered there are a lot of resources available online. Websites, books, workbooks, podcasts, youtube etc. Your just looking at from the wrong angle. Food isnt the issue. Your mental health is. The first thing i did was put the desire to stop binging and to start loosing weight away and changed the focus to mental health because focusing on the food is going to keep you in this cycle.

Ive had disability tax credit for 10 years having never been on disability. It's a totally separate thing. They have their qualifications for disability. If your on disability im sure it's easier to get approved but i got approved simply with my doctor filling out my form and my history. This will be the first year i am going on odsp and my disability tax is actually set for renewal cause its been 10 years. When you are approved for disability tax you are able to start the rdsp. Just to clarify. You are eligible for RDSP when you get approved for the disability tax credit. This is federal and does not require ODSP. They will determine your eligibility when you send in the disability tax forms but you DO need to be approved for the disability tax credit in order to open an RDSP. So your steps will be to apply for disability tax credit. Once approved. You can go to a bank and open an rdsp

I think you are on the right track. Someone who understands why people have eating disorders and someone who can hopefully give you skills to combat it. The best thing you can do for yourself right now is be kinder to yourself. This harsh criticism and judgement you have of yourself is actually exasperating your symptoms. If you can break this shame cycle its a good first step. Think about if your friend came to you with this issue. Would you tell them they're disgusting and a big fat truck? I doubt it... Think about what you would say to a friend and say that to yourself because thats what you need. To need to tell yourself it's okay. Your dealing with an eating disorder and you are doing your best. Don't beat yourself up for eating just say it's okay and try to move forward. Give yourself props for trying to find help. Thats not easy to do and its not easy to avocate for yourself and find a new therapist. You are doing what you need to do and you need to give that process time. Treat yourself like you would a friend. Be kind, be comforting, be validating, because you may think bullying yourself will kick your ass into gear but its doing the opposite.

I'm more predisposed to being heavier too but that has nothing to do with binging. Binging is a psychological problem that's used as a coping skill. Binging is not related to metabolism or hunger. Someone can certainly overeat if their metabolism or hunger works in such a way but binging is a separate issue. Binging is a loss of control. You don't have a loss of control because you have a "fat gene" you have a loss of control because you dont having proper coping skills to deal with emotions, thoughts, or problems effectively. Its the exact same issue that causes alcoholism and drug addiction. I spent 7 years morbidly obese and 10 years before that flipping from skinny to fat. Going on and off diets my whole life. Diets arent sustainable. They don't get to the root of the binge problem which is psychological. I have finally beat binge eating and it was because i got mental health help. Now i have lost 80 pounds WITHOUT diet or exercise. Purely from recovering from binge eating. I will never naturally be a 120 pound woman but it is definitely not natural for me to be 300 pounds. What is realistic for me is probably upper normal range or a little overweight. THAT is relative to metabolism, and predisposition. Unless you have a real medical problem no ones body is naturally going to sit at morbidly obese. That is from thee binge eating. If you solve the binge eating your body will loose weight naturally and return to its normal form but binging is not natural and is not a predisposed condition.
Its hectic for this season.

There were a few things that began my recovery. 1. Change in perception. I was diagnosed with binge eating disorder. Even went through a BED program but I hadn't really accepted the diagnosed and accepted it was a mental health problem. Mostly because I thought it was just my fault. I just thought I was lazy, liked food to much, had no will power. I just blamed myself and thought im just i lazy fatass and could change my weight If i wanted too but im just too lazy. The shift came when I started to realize that everytime i felt sad, anxious, angry, the first thing that popped into my mind was food. What was i going to eat when i got the chance. That realization that my food intake was linked to my emotions was big. It made me realize that i had a bad relationship with food. That food was my drug of choice. I wasn't a drug addict or alcoholic but if i could very easily be. This is when i realized .. Wow. This is a mental illness. This isnt in my control at this point. I accepted that i am going to have to treat this like a mental illness and accept I don't have power over it right now and that its going to be a process because a quick fix diet isnt going to change the fact that i use food to cope with my emotions. A diet doesn't address why i eat when im sad and why I only get pleasure from eating. 2. I got into a mental health program. I got lucky. I was dealing with another mental illness that got me into a dialectical behavioural therapy program. DBT fits very well with a BED diagnoses because ppl with bed often lack coping skills and awareness of their emotions and DBT is a therapy that addresses just that. So at the same time i was having this realization it was because i was in a program which was forcing me to notice my emotions more. This helped me link the eating to my mental health AND taught me different coping skill that were effective which has helped tremendously in getting the binging under control. 3. I stopped dieting, weighing myself, and focusing on my weight. I knew if i could beat BED my weight would start to reduce naturally. I promised to focus on my mental health and accepted that for the time being I would be over weight and had to be okay with that. I knew if I could overcome the eating disorder i would find long term weightloss and not have to deal with this again. I also made a realistic expectation. I said to myself. I have to be okay with giving this time. I told myself its going to take at least a year or 2 to beat bed and to see results. No more quick fixes. I had to prepare to wait and work the program and let my body adjust naturally. I think if you are someone who is still guilting themselves and shaming themselves you may not have accepted the reality of an eating disorder. It may be beneficial to you to read up more about eating disorders as youll likely relate and maybe will see a perception shift. I think its very important to get therapy or get into a program. The best programs focus on CBT and DBT therapy. I found these have been the best when dealing with this. I think a lot of BED programs are working on intuitive eating, etc but that still focuses the problem on the food. The problem isnt the food. Its your mental health. So i would try to find something that focuses on proven mental health therapies like CBT or DBT and once you are in those programs you can add in the intuitive eating, and BED specific stuff. There are also resources online about eating disorders and CBT/DBT therapy. I'm betting there are youtube channels and books dedicated to this treatment.

People only see life through their eyes. If they typically eat small meals maybe to them a binge is eating a large meal and a dessert. Obviously most of these people don't understand the real meaning of binging because they don't have an eating disorder and although it would be ideal for everyone to understand mental health terms it's not necessarily their fault, they are just uninformed. It's the same with ppl who say I'm so depressed when they've dropped their ice cream or something lol. Depression is a serious mental illness. They are obviously not depressed but it has become kind of just a cultural slang you use.I think binge has too. Binge for people who don't have disorders just means over eating to them. I also think its not up to us to determined what constitutes a binge. It's very possible that someone who normally eats 2 pieces of pizza felt out of control when they ate 4 and that would be defined as a binge. A binge isn't really about the amount of food you eat it's the state in which you eat it in. I'm in recovery for binge eating. My binges use to be big. 2-3 McDonald's meals in 1 sitting then maybe 3 desserts after. Now that I'm in recovery i don't eat as much and don't eat the same food but that doesn't mean I'm immune to binges. They do however look much different for me now. A binge for me may just be eating a dessert I normally wouldn't eat, or maybe eating 2 snacks instead of one. It doesn't sound like much but I'm eating them because I'm using it as a way to cope and feel out of control. I feel like i cant help it and im using the food to feel better and that's really what makes a binge. Yes it is typically large sums of food and is usually what is required to diagnose bed but I binged today and it consisted of eating 10 perogies. That may not seem like a binge to most but to me it was because I was upset, i specifically went to food to make me feel better, and i ate more than i normally would while feeling unable to control it. They are not bad people if they say things like this. They do not think they are offending anyone by saying this. If it affects you, you can inform them how what they are saying may be insensitive to ppl with eating disorders. Beyond that I would try not to take it to heart. People are unaware of others pain. It's not being said maliciously. I know its easier to just say oh fuck you but being angry about stuff ppl arent aware of isn't going to serve you. I used to be angry at everything ppl did i thought was wrong and i was angry all the time. It's exhausting to always be angry.

I didnt even know binge eating disorder was a disorder until i was diagnosed and i knew and used the word binge often. Just because people use the word binge doesnt mean they even know what BED is. This is a disorder that is JUST starting to gain recognition. It's completely understandable that a lot of people arent aware of it and use the word binge as they know it ( unrestrained and often excessive indulgence) binge is a term used for drinking, watching tv, spending money) it does not soley mean binge eating disorder and it doesn't have to.

Bayleigh trying not to yell because ppl have called her crazy which has lead to her trying to avoid any conflict but this has also caused her to become overly emotional when she feels shes forced into an argument. Shes trying to prove shes nice and gets angry when she feels bayday are trying to paint her as a villan. David doesnt trust ANYONE because of the ppl he played with last season. We all saw how nicole acted because of her last season. This is no longer their personality this is all due to what the bb community did to them when they left the house. Everyone in there is WAY more concerned about their image and potential backlash then they are out of the house rather than playing a good game and you know whos fault that is? Ours. Because we arent letting them be human. We are screaming racist, crazy, etc at them because we are completely exaggerating situations and love to hate. Ppl mad at what big brother has become? As the years go on the online bullying and cancelling of people is becoming more extreme and it's affecting their mental health greatly. Quite clearly. I dont think we can understand what its like to be attacked 24/7 across all social media platforms and maybe even in person. Image a few ppl bullying you in highschool and then multiply that by thousands. I dont think we can fault these cast members for having anxiety, depression, and straight up trauma from these experiences and we as fans should recognize this isnt them. This isnt their personality this is because of us. We've created these ppl that are absolutely terrified of coming out of the house because they know anything they do will be twisted to fit the internets narrative. I really do think big brother america should be shutdown. It's become this breeding place for toxic behaviour from the fans and though the ppl do benefit from the show. Mineral sunscreens are key i feel if you have acne. For me i use the weightless liquid mineral spf 30 from First Aid Beauty @ Sephora. I used to use Clinique 50 spf but i heard they changed the formula and it isnt great anymore. The first aid beauty is stupid expensive at like $45. The good thing is you need soooo little product to cover your face so it lasts. If your not into spending that much the best drug store sunscreen that has been touted by dermatologists and cosmetologist alike is the Cerave sheer tinted spf 30 or Cerave hydrating spf 30. I haven't tried these as i am still have lots of first aid beauty left but my next purchase im going to try Cerave for something less expensive. I think key for sunscreens too is making sure your doing a good cleanse after a day of wearing sunscreen. I use a scrubbing brush ( light scrub) to make sure I get it all out if my pores. I havent really has an issue since switching to these face specific formulas.

The best thing you can do is tell yourself its okay. Its normal to not eat everyday of your life perfect. 1 bad day isnt going to ruin the progress youve made. Just tell yourself its okay. I actually did this exact thing this week. Ive been in recovery 10 months and have had a lot of changes lately. I binged and I did feel bad but mostly because I was sad that I clearly will still use food if I get too stressed. Anyways i decided to just tell myself its okay and not dwell on it. Its not a failure at all. Its not like you have to start from the beginning. Im still in recovery 10 months. That wont be taken away because i binged one meal. It's more important to have a sustainable eating plan than one that is not. A plan that requires you to eat perfectly 24/7 for the next 60 years just isnt realistic. Part of recovery will be finding acceptance when you do binge or over eat because it absolutely will happen again and thats okay. That is normal. It was one day and tomorrow is a new one. Be kind to yourself, try to just move forward and leave it behind you. Thats it. If you dont dwell and guilt yourself for it you wont have that rebound guilt binge.

A lot of ppl think willpower is an actual thing lol. Will power can be applied IF you have power over things and all it takes is a little will lol. I have no idea why people think mental illness comes down to will power. Its because they have no idea what they are talking about really. People can only relate through their experiences. You say your depressed and someone may think about their worst feeling of depression. Maybe a break up, because they felt depressed they can understand HOW you feel but cant understand WHY you cant get better. Because people without mental illness typically have episodic depression ( based on life events not on chemical imbalance, genetics, trauma, etc) they make the assumption if they can do it so can you. That's where this will power shit comes from. People think they had the will power to get over their exes so you just need will power to get over your mental illness lol. When you have a disorder like this. Especially this one because it is not understood by the regular public at all you have to find some acceptance in the fact that most ppl will not understand and most ppl will probably say the wrong thing. You can either try to have a conversation with them about how you feel when they say things like that you or you have to chalk it up to, they have good intentions but ill have to accept they probably don't have the understanding to comfort me in the way i need. Its shitty. Esp from a SO. You should probably try to speak with them about it but after a while you may have to just have to let it go and find another support system.

Yeah so you need to find a way to distract yourself from not counting calories. Just like binging it's another compulsion but this compulsion adds fuel to the fire. Just like i had to force myself to stop weighing myself everyday. Your first step would be to avoid the temptation to add up those calories in your head. When you get the urge do something else. Find a way to cope with the thoughts of wanting to tally up the food. You may know exactly what you are eating when you are eating it but you still have to do the math to figure out the total and that is something you can work to stop.

Counting calories makes binge eating worse. It like the last thing you should do if you want to get better. Anytime you go over your calories limit you feel shame and guilt and that shame and guilt leads to more binging. If you really want to try to get better stop counting calories and just eat. If you want to lose weight i guarentee you, you will not loose it by going on a diet, not long term anyways. The only way you will loose weight and keep it off is to recover from binge eating disorder and that means stopping problematic behaviours like counting calories, weighing yourself, restricting food. Anything that makes you feel depressed if you dont stick to it you need to stop because binge eating is a coping mechanism and if you keep giving yourself stuff to cope with your going to cope with food. You need to remove as much stuff that can make you feel bad about yourself and the most obvious is a calorie goal, weight goal, and diet goal.

First step. Stop counting calories. Binge eating is a coping mechanism. Everytime you go over your calorie count your going to need to cope with the sadness. Therefore leading to more binges. WRITING.TITLE: Counting calories is making your binge eating disorder worse.
WRITING.TEXT: So many posts the last few days of people stressed out going over their daily/weekly calorie count. Clearly not understanding that counting calories is directly linked to them binging. Let's break it down: Binge eating is a coping mechanism. A coping mechanism is something you do to feel better when you have strong emotions you don't know how to effectively deal with like sadness, anger, shame, guilt, disgust, anxiety, ect. When you force yourself to adhere to a calorie goal you are putting yourself in a situation to have an emotional outcome if you do not stick to your goal. It IS NOT realistic to eat only a certain amount of calories everyday for the rest of your life. You WILL at some point go over those calories and when you do these feelings of sadness, anger, shame, guilt, disgust, or anxiety will come over you. Since you don't have an effective way to deal with those emotions you will binge to make yourself feel better. counting calories = increased binging. This goes the same for weight goals, diet goals, restricting certain foods. It's not a realistic sustainable goal. It will eventually end in failure which will end in a binge. Give yourself a fighting chance and remove that stressor from your life. Remove weighing, counting, restricting. You don't need more things in your life causing you to have an emotional reaction you cant cope with. If you drop these practices from your life it is one less thing leading to a binge. Real talk: the only way you will loose weight AND KEEP IT OFF. Is to recover from binge eating disorder. You will not recover from binge eating disorder if you are doing the above problematic behaviours because it feeds the binging disorder. The problem here is not your willpower or the food you eat. It is your lack of coping skills. Put down the calorie app and pick up a DBT or CBT therapy book to help you learn how to detect your emotions and how to cope with them more effectively. This isn't an appetite issues. It is a mental health issue. You need to treat it as such.

That's where the mental health part comes in. It's not like your body has just forgotten what hunger is. It's that you have spent so much time using food for a different purpose thats what you are associating it with. Ive been in recover 10 months. Ive lost 80 pounds. I could have never focused on this eating disorder until i focused on my mental health. If you don't have that bit sorted or at very least started the binge eating is going to be a real battle. BED is a symptom not a cause. It's a symptom of a mental health issue. I started by completely stopping my attempts to stop BED and loose weight. I did that because i knew this would go on forever if i didn't address my mental health. I accepted that it may take me a year or longer but if I don't fix the mental health bit ill never fix the binge eating. So i accepted that i would be overweight, that i would continue to eat, and i accepted that reality for now because i was sick of the yoyo-ing. I wanted to find long term success. Thing is once i did that everything changed. With a new perspective i actually started loosing weight naturally within the first month of this new outlook. Because i was focused on the mental part and not the physical part I naturally didn't feel the binge urges as much and even when i did because i wasn't beating myself up about it so i didn't have rebound guilt binges. Without trying i was loosing weight. I know it sounds crazy. But in order to loose weight you have to give up trying to loose weight. I NEVER thought i would be down 80 pounds and counting in less than a year. I had accepted that probably wouldn't happen for a long time. As soon as i gave up trying to control everything it all occured naturally. It is Extremely hard to give up control. Eating disorders are all about control but thats exactly why you have to give it up. Find acceptance and work on the important part which is learning about your emotions and how to cope with them. Mentally its been a journey but physically its been the easiest weight loss ive ever had lol. Ive finally learned how to eat like normal because i was no longer worrying about what i was eating. Now im able to eat a variety of food without seeing it as good or bad but just seeing it as food. This will all come naturally as you recover but the first step is changing something. Dieting clearly isnt working, counting calories clearly isnt working, try something different, try the opposite. Most success stories you see started with ppl stopping these restrictive behaviours. Its like that for a reason.

Yes. This is what youve been told. And yes, this would be the case if you didnt have an eating disorder but if you are on this sub i assume you do and by feeding into this diet culture you are exasperating your eating disorder. What do you think is worse for you? Eating a variety of food everyday, eating moderately, and eating proper portions. Or starving yourself for days and then binging thousands of calories in a day or sitting. Ill tell you, its the first one. The way you get to the first one is by concurring the eating disorder. Not only will you not loose weight effectively while still dealing with an eating disorder you will have far worse health issues because of this binge, starve cycle. Its far better to eat a little worse everyday while maintaining proper portions than to eat within such extremes. I have not been counting my calories AT ALL since being in recovery but i can tell you for damn sure i am eating more on a daily bases than i did before. I am certainly NOT exercising the calories i eat off because i dont exercise at all. So with that logic i should be gaining or maintaining weight, right? Yet ive some how lost 80 pounds. All due to the fact i just dont binge anymore. Your body will 100% react more favorably to a regular moderate diet than it will with this extreme change from day to day. Thats the reality. Look at other success stories. If it works for you thats fine but all I hear is diet culture bullshit that doesn't help most ppl with BED. Its a tired narrative that is starting to disappear because it only brings on short term success.
