Absolutely. I'm close to a year in recovery. I would say the first 1-2 months were the most difficult but a lot of it really is just breaking the habit. When you break the habit of going to food when your upset etc. Whatever youre doing instead will become the new normal. Keep sticking with it, it will absolutely pay off and is possible. I think the key is of course using coping skills and also for the first bit trying your hardest to reduce your stress so you can make it easier on yourself. Ive been in recovery a while now and when I get really upset i definitely still have the urge to binge. I have binged a few times in recovery but the difference is its not the end of the world anymore because I know ive got the skills to get back on track. Im also able to fight the urge a lot easier now because im so much more aware of the other things i can to do cope. When you build up an arsenal of skills to use instead of food it'll become a lot easier to choose the 10 other things you can do instead but it takes time for your brain to disassociate food with with making you feel better. I'll be at a year soon. I NEVER thought it would be possible to be here in my recovery. If you keep going soon this will be you!

It's certainly in the same spectrum. OCD tendencies often come about as a coping mechanism so does binge eating. I bet if you went into therapy for OCD it would help your binge eating as well because the type of therapy you would get for ocd would focus on alternative coping skills therefore helping both illnesses. Hopefully how that you have a diagnoses you can find proper treatment and be closer to recovery. If you have an option CBT or DBT therapy is the best. If you can find a program that has group therapy to teach these skills AND allows for individual sessions that's usually the best route to go.

Its very hard to because a lot of progress is made in challenging your perceptions and beliefs about stuff and that can be very difficult to do on your own. It often takes an outside observation or a trained professional to help you realize what you haven't seen yourself. Not everyone can get into these programs though especially if you are in a country that doesnt have universal health care. In that case your next best scenario may be going through a workbook on your own. If you go on amazon there are workbooks on DBT for binge eating disorder, or CBT for OCD. The program i was in used the marsha linden DBT workbook and another program i was in used a workbook from amazon as well so these are legitimate books that are being used by professionals. I would also try to find a youtube channel or podcast you like. There will be hundreds on these subjects. Maybe from someone in recovery or from a professional but watching/listening to others perspectives and ideas can help open up your mind to things you may not be seeing.

If you really want to lose weight don't weigh yourself through this process. Weighing will absolutely trigger binging if you don't see what you like. If you avoid it, you won't get emotional about it, and it won't have an effect on your mood and therefore your disorder. I went for 3 months without weighing myself. Without knowing it I lost 25 pounds. The minute I started weighing myself again, I started binging because I was putting myself in a position for disappointment. Let it happened naturally. If you stop binging you will absolutely lose weight naturally but 1 week isn't going to be an indication of anything and if you monitor it you are playing right into the disorder. You either focus on your binging, mental health, coping skills... or doing the opposite; dieting, weighing, restricting. Try something different this time. You may be surprised by the outcome. Avoiding the urge to weigh is just as important as avoiding the urge to binge with this disorder.

Real talk lol. You'll lose weight by recovering from binge eating disorder but the chances of you recovering from binge eating disorder by trying to loose weight isnt likely. Loosing weight, restricting food, counting calories, and weighing yourself are the most common reasons people don't recover from BED. Anytime you have a goal set out for yourself that revolves around loosing weight youre feeding the eating disorder. This happens because your setting up goals for yourself that revolves around a big part of the reason you have an eating disorder... Your self image. Everytime you fail at one of these goals ( and you will fail because the goals are not sustainable 24/7) it then triggers the other reason you have an eating disorder and thats lack of coping skills. You are quite literally doing the opposite of what you should be doing with an eating disorder. You may not want to hear it but you need to stop trying to lose weight to lose weight. Put the weight loss aside for 6 months to a year. Quit dieting, weighing, and restricting. Switch your focus to your mental health. Get in an ED program or a therapy program that involves cbt or dbt therapy. Learn how to identify your emotions and how to cope with the effectively. A lot of the times when ppl have removed the pressure of weight loss and have successfully started to identify alternative coping mechanisms the binge eating gets better. When the binge eating gets better the weight loss comes naturally. I did this exact thing 11 months ago. I quit dieting, weighing, and trying to loose weight. I accepted the weight i was at FOR NOW so i could focus on my mental health. It meant i accepted the binges for what they were because I knew the way out was through mental health help. Its labeled a mental illness for a reason. It was funny because once i actively and truly stopped trying to lose weight... The weight actually started falling off. No diet, no exercise, no restricting, no anything. The reason it was coming off was simply because i wasn't binging as much. Some of that happened just because I stopped focusing on weight loss. The rest of the binging stopped when I learned effective mental health skills. Ive lost 85 pounds and counting in the last 11 months. It's physically been the most and easiest weightloss ive ever had and the really great part about it... Is i know for the first time i may actually stay this way because I have learned how to stop the thing that kept me yo-yoing. You will never find long term weightloss without recovery. You may find weightloss but it won't be because you beat BED if your doing it by dieting or calorie counting. Its not easy. Its a big mind fuck. Stop trying to lose weight to lose weight, i mean wtf right lol. But it works for us with BED. We arent going to benefit from "willpower" we are not like the average eater. We have a mental illness and it needs to be treated as such. Binging is a symptom. You need to fix the root problem if you want to get better. No amount of restricting. Or calorie counting regardless if its just "maintenance" counting will fix a mental illness. The calories are not the issue here. Your mental health is.

Yeah. That's why I had to make it not about the food anymore because nothing I did made any difference. It wasnt until I found help for my mental health did I realize all of these rules, tricks, diets, etc really had no barring on my eating. It was all mental health related. Hense BED being called a mental illness. Its kinda like drug addiction isn't really about drugs. It's their method to cope but its ultimately not because they love meth soooo much. Which is why drug addiction is treated in mental health hospitals.

It's not easy. It requires a really big change in perception. The few things that helped change my perception was: 1. I realized my emotions were completely linked to why I binge. I felt sad, angry, anxious, basically anything and my first thought was... What am I going to eat. That made me realize it really did have nothing to do with food or willpower. It was linked to my emotions which are linked to my mental health. I clearly was using food as a coping mechanism and if I wanted to beat binge eating I had to fix the source of it. Which was mental health 2. After that realization I knew the only way out was to focus on getting better. I had a lot of radical accepting to do. I had to accept I had an eating disorder, which is a mental illness, which will only get better if treated as such. I accepted that since it was a mental illness it was going to take time to get better. I accepted that if I wanted to get better I had to stop putting my focus in areas that didnt solve the problem ( dieting, etc) and put it on areas that would (mental health). I accepted that there would be no quick fix which meant I had to accept being obese for a while ( this was probably the hardest one). I told myself id probably be looking at 1-2 years minimum to beat an eating disorder and I had to accept that this is just the way im going to have to look for that time while I get better. Id dealt with being obese for 7 straight years and on and off for years before that. Whats 2 more years if it cures me for the rest of my life.. I had to accept that realistic timeline. Diets have warped my mind to thinking theres a quick fix to everything but this wasnt going to be the same. I knew if I could focus all my attention on mental health that I would eventually get better and hopefully never have to deal with being obese again because Ive finally stopped the source of the binging 3. I vowed to stop doing everything that had never worked. Diets, restricting, counting calories, weighing myself. They haven't work for 7+ years. It was time to change the approach. 4. I no longer wanted to focus on weight. I was completely focused on health. I focused on what I wanted to feel not what i wanted to look like. I had IBS, painful cystic acne, an autoimmune disorder that was outta control, I was exhausted all the time, and always had aches and pains. I focused on how to make those things better and that did require removing some things from my diet but it was amazing because when I focused on what I wanted to feel like vs look like it didnt trigger binges what so ever. The consequence was no longer " im going to stay fat" it was "i dont feel good right now" and that immediate consequence of eating food that isnt good for me is what drove me to adopt a healthier eating habit. It's a happy bonus I lost weight but more importantly I got rid of my acne, I healed my gut, my autoimmune disease reduced 3 stages, I even noticed my mood lift. I didnt give up foods i like though. I only gave up foods if they caused me physical pain. The change in perception seemed really vital for me to be successful Its funny because as soon as I did all that. It only took about a month or 2 to start loosing weight lol. I was working on my mental health but the simple act of quitting problematic behaviours, accepting my life as it was, and changing the focus to listening to my body instead of my mind, helped stop alot of binge urges. It's been 10 months. Ive lost 80 pounds. No diet, no exercise. Just proper mental health care. I did a DBT program. CBT is good as well. An ED program based on one of these therapies is best, if you have access to it.
Oh man ive dreamed of going to japan. I mean their manners/values really do seem impeccable lol.
Yeah this is scary.
No problem at all! That's amazing. It's a journey but it is possible to recover even though it doesn't feel like it at times. I wish you well!

For me personally I have other mental health issues as well. I suffer from BPD which usually comes with depression, anxiety, etc. I have a feeling though that BED is a symptom of other issues. Not nessesarily a full blown disorder like me but im sure chronic depression and anxiety will be the case for alot of ppl with BED so the first step is usually to get a proper diagnoses. Im in Canada so the system here works differently than some other countries but my steps were: 1. To get my family doctor to refer me for a psychiatric assessment. If you already haven't had one ideally research some facilities ( usually hospitals or mental health facilities) that have programs for Eating disorders, CBT or DBT therapy and ask to go for your assessment there. The place that will do your assessment will likely refer you to one of their programs so its good to go somewhere you want to try to get into to. If you haven't been assessed properly before this its probably the hardest first step because general practitioners will try to treat you themselves first. Often with antidepressants, or anxiety meds( which could be very helpful for overall mental health and MAY help reduce binges but will not solve the problem long term as therapy is required). Alot of doctors are starting to prescribe stimulants as well for appetite control for BED. I strongly suggest you refuse this option until you have had a psychiatric assessment as this is a serious drug, with serious side effects, that does not help mood, it really only helps to control appetite which sounds lovely but that's not your issue and will not solve your issue. If the specialist wants to prescribe these along with a mental health program I can see the benefit that may bring but do not let your GP push pills on you without any therapy components. You have to be your own avocate when it comes to mental health. That's why its great to research programs on your own and bring them specifically to your doctors and ask them to refer you there. I would even go on the programs websites, print out the referral forms, and bring them to my doctors office to sign lol. A proper diagnoses is soooo important because it opens the door up to speciality programs that you may otherwise not have access to unless you paid for a private program. In Canada mental health is covered if you are referred out by your doctor. If not your option is to go private which is extremely expensive. If you have the money, great. If not you may have to jump through some hoops and insist to your doctor this is what you require. BED could also be a symptom of a deeper problem, and unchecked disorder ( not always the case) so this is why an assessment is really important. It can really be a turning point especially if you have something undiagnosed you aren't aware of. If you don't then you know the eating disorder is the only thing you need to focus on. Its a win win. Information is power. 2. Started researching information that I could help myself with. Like I said DBT and CBT therapy is going to be the best kind of therapy for BED. I really think DBT is gold standard. These days there are lots of online tools you can use that may help while you wait for a referral or if you simply can't afford care ( if you dont have insurance). Look up books/workbooks for binge eating disorder. When I google DBT for binge eating disorder quite a few websites pop up so go check those out. See if they offer any material. Similarly if you search DBT for binge eating on amazon a few books come out. I am sure those will be great resources to get you started. Youtube and podcasts also have great information. Search youtube or even google best youtube/podcasts for binge eating. Youll find professionals and people in recovery that can give you tips on how to move forward. Note: Intuitive eating has been a popular treatment for BED but personally I dont think it gets to the root of the problem, as intuitive eating still focuses ALL on the food which isn't the main issue. Thats why I continue to say focus on CBT or DBT. These programs are made to change the way you think about the world in general. It gives you effective coping skills and helps you notice your emotions. this is a very important component to recovery. Once you have gone through the DBT program then an intuitive eating program will be great if you are still struggling with the food part. 3. That perspective change. Telling myself my mental health is the most important thing so trying to put myself in an ideal situation to make that happen. Making sure I had the time so I could do the program. Making sure I was avoiding situations that caused me extreme stress. Making sure I stopped focusing on what didnt work like ( dieting, etc) and focusing just on how to fix the mental health bit. Researching a ton so i understood the eating disorder and what steps i needed to take to solve it.
Am I the only one who sees a cat in a post about acne?

Wellbutrin is a pretty good med for depression. Its well tolerated. Its been the med ive stayed on the longest. Wellbutrin will help your mood but it won't cure your binge eating disorder. A lift in mood can certainly contribute to less urges and less binges and maybe a remission in binge eating due to feeling mentally better but the source of your binge eating still remains which means the chance of you relapsing is likely. This is because binge eating is a coping mechanism. If you feel better mentally you may not need to cope as much which is why it helps but as soon as an event happens, life gets hard, maybe the medication looses its effect, you will turn to binging again because you actually haven't learned how to cope effectively. I think wellbutrin is a great medication but if youre using it primarily to treat BED you need a therapy component or you'll find yourself coming back to binging. Just want to put that out there. Ive been on antidepressants for 15 years and my BED did come and go but it wasnt until I got into a dbt therapy program did I actually recover from it. You need that duel treatment to make sure you dont fall back into BED and can truly recover. I would personally suggest avoiding vyvanse unless you have adhd. It has a lot of side effects and can make your quality of life worse, in my opinion. I would recommend an antidepressant/therapy route first before you try stimulants.

There is no difference between fasting and restricting. In fact you are fasting and restricting since you have a calorie limit lol. Anytime you restrict anything about the way you eat ( the type of food, the calories, the time, etc, ) you are restricting. It seems you know restricting is not good for BED but maybe not why. Restricting is bad because putting rules on your eating isn't sustainable. There is no reality that exists that you are going to be able to eat like this every single day of your life till you are 80 years old. This is a problem because when we can't eat within the rules we see it as a "failure" and that triggers a binge. Essentially you are causing binges by trying to stop binging. The reason we binge is because we use it as a coping mechanism. We don't know effective ways to deal with our emotions so we eat. That why when we perceive a failure we binge. It brings up sadness, guilt, shame, and the only way we know how to deal with it is to binge. The reason you find it hard not to continuously eat throughout the day has really nothing to do with your inability to stop, your inability to listen to hunger cues, or your willpower in general. Its because you have constant emotions or thoughts that you don't know how to deal with. You may not even realize you have these emotions which is why a lot of people don't put it together that this is the reason for their binging. Binge eating disorder is a mental illness for a reason. Its the same reason drug addiction is a mental illness. Food is just the coping mechanism, it isn't the actual problem. If you want to recover from BED you need mental health care for your mental illness. A diet will not result in long term recovery. You may find short term success but if you don't fix the root problem it will keep coming back over and over and over to help you cope when things get hard. I've been in recovery for 11 months after struggling for 15 years. I didnt have recovery until i QUIT all diets and focused on my mental health. No diet can will be able to cure mental illness. Sorry to say. Finding a DBT or CBT therapy program is best for BED. If you can't get into a program there are books on amazon that cover DBT for binge eating disorder. There are also youtube channels and podcasts that can give you good information.

Can I point something out to you? You are prefacing you are so proud of yourself with its dumb and you hate doing it. The way we speak to and about ourselves can be very important when dealing with mental illness. Dialectics are a simple things we can observe and change. Your first sentence didn't need to exist in this case. You could have simply said "I #8217;ve gone 2 days without binging or restricting and I #8217;m so proud". Dont minimize your achievement with negative self talk. You are allowed to be proud and you should be proud. Its not dumb at all. For some people 1 meal not binging is an accomplishment so 2 days is fantastic. Dont minimize your achievements especially if you are proud of them. Combating those thoughts that make you feel the need to give yourself an insult before you compliment yourself could be really great for your mental health. So congrats! You have the right to be proud of it.

I had no issue with dairy until a few years ago. It's pretty common for ppl to loose the ability to break down lactose as they age. Dairy is hard because there could be a few reasons its causing inflammation; the lactose, fat, or hormones. For me I thought it was the fat but I started buying lactose free cheese to see if it made a difference and it does seem to. Ive been eating lactose free cheese for a few months now and havent had any noticable related flaring compared to regular cheese so I guess for me its the lactose. Kind of trial an error i guess because I cant eat dairy free ice cream since it still has a lot of sugar and sugar is a trigger for me. As for the bloating in hands, feet, etc. I haven't particularly noticed that but inflammation can do wild things. The last time i had a major flare up the lympnodes in my neck were swollen for a week, that was scary. So its possible. For me if i notice swelling like that I usually attribute it too retaining water. In that case i try to reduce my sodium intake and drink plenty of water.

WRITING.TITLE: Brain Scans Clarify Borderline Personality Disorder
WRITING.TEXT: Sometimes I find it really hard to accept my emotional outbursts and issues are because of BPD. Sometimes I feel like its a fake diagnoses or a cop out to explain why im a difficult person (This is my own self-hate and not what I believe about others with BPD) but studies like this, though small, help me to see the reality that there is a difference with my brain and there really is a reason I can't regulate my emotions like others. I duno maybe it will help someone else. #8203; "Using real-time brain imaging, a team of researchers have discovered that patients with Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) are physically unable to regulate emotion. The findings, by Harold W. Koenigsberg, MD, professor of psychiatry at Mount Sinai School of Medicine suggest individuals with BPD are unable activate neurological networks that would help to control feelings. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), researchers viewed how the brains of people with BPD reacted to social and emotional stimuli. Koenigsberg found that when people with BPD attempted to control and reduce their reactions to disturbing emotional scenes, the anterior cingulate cortex and intraparetical sulci areas of the brain that are active in healthy people under the same conditions remained inactive in the BPD patients. #8220;This research shows that BPD patients are not able to use those parts of the brain that healthy people use to help regulate their emotions, #8221; said Dr. Koenigsberg. #8220;This may explain why their emotional reactions are so extreme. The biological underpinnings of the disordered emotional control systems are central to borderline pathology. Studying which areas of the brain function differently in patients with borderline personality disorder can lead to more targeted uses of [psychotherapy](https://psychcentral.com/psychotherapy/) and [medications](https://psychcentral.com/drugs/), and also provide a link to connect the genetic basis of the disorder. #8221; #8203; [Brain scans clarify borderline personality disorder](https://psychcentral.com/news/2017/09/04/brain-scans-clarify-borderline-personality-disorder/8184.html)

WRITING.TITLE: Anyone here have, or suspect they may have Lupus?
WRITING.TEXT: Apparently HS is linked to lupus. Ive always wondered if I have lupus. I often have red cheeks and on occassion have seen what looks like a butterfly rash. I duno if id call it a rash though, more like redness, but maybe thats all a rash is lol. I had it pretty intensely today which is why its sparked my curiosity again. Anyways i feel like a lot of symptoms overlap with HS and i know it's difficult to get diagnosed for any autoimmune disease but I was wondering if anyone here has been successfully diagnosed and if this is something i should peruse further. My symptoms are getting worse as i get older even though I've recovered alot from HS through diet change. When I do get a flare up not only is the HS bad but I am severely sick. Last time to the point my neck swelled up for a week. I'm anemic, photosensitive, have dry eyes, and have memory loss. I feel like these are all common conditions for other things too though. Its seems so general lol but I just want to be informed so i can get better treatment for myself if its out there and also so I know if I need to monitor myself more closely. Anyone suspect lupus and been diagnosed? If so what symptoms did you have and how hard was it to get a diagnoses? [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5895357/](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5895357/)

Dry eyes are common with lupus. Usually what happens with dry eyes are the glands get blocked and that's why your eyes cant produce as much moisture. Blocked glands can also lead to inflammation which will lead to styes etc. The best treatment is a warm compress over your eyes for 10 minutes. You can use a warm wash cloth or you can buy a bean bag eye mask to use. Start with 10 minutes a day. Trust me you will feel the difference immediately. Once youve done that a week or two you can start reducing it to a few times a week and then maybe once a week. The heat helps unclogged the glands so they can work properly. Cleaning your lids is another important step to help keep your eyes healthy. Cleaning your lash line with lid wipes or baby shampoo will stop them from getting clogged. Eye drops can help ease symptoms and help get that moisture back in your eye so they are good to use regularly but the heat and lid cleaning may stop that issue completely. Omega 3 fish oil supplements are also great for the eyes and inflammatory conditions . Ive worked in the eye care business for over 10 years. Worked with doctors, surgeon's and helped to treat patients. This is the advice we give our patients. If none of this helps there are prescription drops that can be prescribed but theyll tell you to try all this first.

This giant dog sat in a small apartment all day, got no training, and walks consisted of around the block and to a small park across the street. I mean what is the point? Lol. It's like she got the dog just to tell everyone its pure bred from germany but didn't actually live a lifestyle appropriate for a big, active , dog like that. I took the poor dog on a hike through the forest once and the dog was so tired after an hour of walking it was practically limping by the time we got home. That's how unfit the dog was. It was heart wrenching. The dog was a menace because it was never trained. It only took me 3 walks to train her to not pull on a leash. She was smart as hell but would never reach her potential because the owner cared more about some status symbol than what the dog actually needed.

DBT is going to be the best therapy for you. Recovery is a journey for most people. Ive done the full DBT program twice now and before that a CBT program along with some in patient and hospital programs. Ive definitely gotten better with this round of DBT. Some would say remission. I think a lot of things have to fall in place to find remission. Its not just about therapy and medication a lot can do with where you are in life, what's your mental outlook on things, who are your facilitators in the program etc. I say this because the first time I did the DBT program I did find it to be helpful but I still didn't recover. There were still a lot of factors/stressors in my life that were holding me back from recovery that I didnt realize. This round of DBT happened after kind of a rock bottom. I was back home because I was homeless, no job, no friends, and bankrupt. Though that seems like a tough scenario to get better in, it actually changed my perspective on a lot of things. So much so I was more open than ever to learning and getting better. I could also solely focus on my mental health and frankly i just worked better with the therapist i had on this team compared to the others. Im not saying it takes a long hard road like it did for me but im just saying everyone has their own journey. You could be in the best DBT program with the best therapist but your life circumstances, mental focus, or whatever isn't in line at this time which is why it could take a little while to figure it all out. We also get wiser with age so I think its realistic to not expect to find remission right away. BPD is known as a very up and down type of illness. The road to recovery is often very wavy and that's okay. We learn from these ups and down. For medication wellbutrin has worked well for me. Little side effects and keeps my major depressive symptoms at bay. I did well on lamotrigine for a while as well but eventually it stopped working and I'm pretty sure i gained massive weight from it. Antipsychotics are the absolute worst! Ive heard a lot of ppl say similar things on here. My general sense is they arent right for BPD but that's just what i gather. As for dating I personally have taken a break from dating about 5 or 6 years now. Ive done so because i was really sick for a long time and relationships are major stressors for me and always made me sicker so I decided if i was going to get better I need to get better on my own. I also knew id never be in a healthy relationship anyways if i didn't get better so there was no point for me to try while still sick. I dont think you should think about it as an all or nothing thing. Im either going to date or not date. I think if you believe its best to avoid it for now for your mental health thats okay. Allow yourself to heal and to learn so hopefully you can take that knowledge into your next relationship but if you live in absolutes like I cannot date it may be a hard rule to live by and could just add to your suffering. Maybe dont seek it out for now to focus on yourself but also don't push away people if they bring you joy or peace.

My mom got me a Bissell BarkBath for my bday and ive actually used it quite a lot since she cant get regular groomings right now. Its not perfect but it works to keep her smelling fresh. She'll still need a proper grooming but waaaay less often than before. It works like a couch cleaner lol but for dogs. The handle sprays water and shampoo and sucks it up at the same time. So they arent soaking wet. The bissell comes with no rinse shampoo so even if you don't get it all off its okay. I bathe her right in our livingroom with a few towels laid down. It's honestly so much easier than hauling her into the bathtub lol. Shes a mixed breed but has hair similar to a golden retriever just a little shorter. The wand works well with this type of hair in my opinion. If you buy it on amazon you could always return if it doesnt work. Just a suggestion. Ive saved a lot of money in groomings being able to bathe her between full cuts. I got the black and green one which is cheaper than the newer one they have. I got mine on amazon I think it was like $100. Not bad considering 1 grooming for her costs me $75

A diet makes binge eating disorder worse. Binge eating is a mental illness. It's not about the food your eating its why your eating it and why you lose control when eating it. If you dont fix the mental health part you may lose weight in the short term but chances are you will gain it back when you get in hard place in life. This is because most of us use food as a coping mechanism. If you dont learn effective coping mechanisms you will continue to use food as your go to which means a diet won't help you because you will eventually go back to food. If you want to loose weight permanently it means putting the focus on the source of the mental illness and not the symptoms. Binging is a symptom of a greater problem. I would suggest putting this new found determination to work on your mental health. If you can find a dbt or cbt program one that deals with binge eating is best but these programs are good in their own too. If thats not an option look into DBT for binge eating disorders. You can find books, websites, podcasts, and youtube channel about this. Most people start recovery by actually quitting dieting, quitting weighing themselves, and quitting calorie counting etc. This is because all these things are very triggering for our binge eating disorder. When we dont reach our goals and see it as a "failure" it leads to more binging because a lot of us have self esteem and self image issues, and without healthy coping mechanisms we binge to cope with that failure. Basically by trying not to binge it leads to more binging. Many of us have gone on diet after diet and there is a reason it never sticks. Its not willpower its because we arent addressing the actual issue. Which is mental illness. If you want to lose weight and lose weight for good a diet is the opposite of what you need. You actually need to stop trying to lose weight to lose weight. Focus in your mental health, beat binge eating disorder, and the weight will fall of naturally. Ive lost 85 pounds and counting in under a year without diet or exercise. Recovering from BED was all that needed to happen for the weight to fall off. I spent the past year focusing on my mental health through DBT. As my suffering reduced so did my binge urges and my urges to eat shitty food. I now eat all kinds of foods but with the ability to eat it in moderation. I finally feel free and it started with me promising never to diet again.

1. I do it as a hobby. I got into it because my friend and I were on vacation. She had scuba dived before and we were looking for something to do. I said i would be interested in trying it and thats all it took to fall in love! 2. I would say any adventurous activity can be dangerous but if we follow our training and safety protocols it's pretty safe. Some dangers you can face are weather/ocean currents ( they can be strong so we have to make sure we are informed and don't dive when the conditions aren't good), equipment failure ( sometimes equipment can fail this is why its important to train for those scenarios and check your gear properly before starting your dive), wildlife ( you shouldn't be interfering with marine life. For the most part if you just observe and leave them be they will let you be but when going into a wild environment with wild animals there will always be some risk of an animal reacting in a defensive way) 3. Scuba diving is very fun!! The funnest part is being part of another world. Seeing animals in their natural habitat acting like your just one of them is so cool! There really is no thrill like a turtle, or stingray, or shark swimming by you. Its a rush. It's also fun because you just never know what you're going to see. It's always a surprise. You also get to ride in boats which is fun, male new friends, and be part of a community with a lot of cool interesting people. 4. When water is too warm, corals will expel the algae living in their tissues causing the coral to turn completely white. This is called coral bleaching. When a coral bleaches, it is not dead. Corals can survive a bleaching event, but they are under more stress and are subject to mortality 5. I think every creature has it's own unique intelligence but if we are talking about intelligence like humans problem solving, social, etc. I would say dolphins, orcas, whales, seals, octopus, are the ones ive come across that we're very impressive with their skills. 6. Underwater plants provide food, oxygen, and shelter. 7. I thought it would be really cool to see what was living in the water. 8. I think marine animals can be similar to land animals. Most animals can form a bond with another animal or human. Whether it's because you offer them food or they are simply curious by you I think it is possible for certain marine animals to form a connection with you. 9. I've been lucky enough to not have seen any distressed marine animals so I have never saved an animal is the water but would absolutely try to if I saw one. We do often clean up trash if we come by it in the ocean. Plastic and fishing lines are common to find and animals can die from eating or getting trapped within them so id like to think im helping them out by removing it from the ocean. 10. Yes I have. Jellyfish, stingrays, lionfish, and puffer fish i have seen a lot in the ocean. They can all be poisonous to humans. Like any other animals if you stay away from them they will likely stay away from you. I am happy to say i have never been stung by any of these animals. They are beautiful to watch though!. 11. For me the best experiences are when I see the big animals. On one dive we were absolutely surrounded by sharks 30 or more we saw on our dive. It was intense but thrilling. The sharks were very docile but just the thrill of being in that environment was so cool.
I dont think any of what I said contradicts itself. I think if you've been trying something for a long time like dieting, maybe its time for a different approach.

Its not just what worked for me its what works with most successful recoveries. Of course there can be other ways to get better but this is the proven, researched, and most used by health professionals for a reason. If someone finds help other ways that's great but dieting is often to the detriment of the person with an ED. I'm not blindly encouraging her because I actually care to help her. I see a problematic behaviour that typically leads to worsening of symptoms and I want to make her aware of that in case she wasn't aware. She has the ability to ignore my advice if she wants but I'm not going to go on a anorexia forum and encourage diets just like I'm not going to do that here. Its generally a bad idea. BED is an eating disorder for a reason it has the same mental health issues related to it that anorexia and bulimia have. Its important on this forum to know that. Society has told us that if we are fat its because we like food to much and have no will power. I'm trying to create awareness around the fact that this is not a willpower issue. This is a mental health issue. The eating part is secondary to the mental health part. You can choose to ignore what i say if you like, that's okay, but these are the facts we know about eating disorders. I'm sorry, but I will not encourage someone with an eating disorder to engage in a known behaviour that worsens eating disorder. I think it's wonderful people on here are encouraging but I think knowledge is power and thats my way of encouraging her. Maybe something I say will allow for a perspective change. A change that could lead to recovery. Encouraging a behaviour thats clearly been done in the past and is a known trigger is not helpful in my opinion.

I think there are a lot of ways to go about it and alot of different methods. I can certainly see how it gets confusing. All i was told about for the longest time was intuitive eating and that did absolutely nothing for me. For me i think it was the fact that intuitive eating still has to do with the food. Personally i had to take all the focus off of the food and my weight. I focused soley on my mental health through DBT therapy. This therapy helped me notice my emotions, which helped me linked my emotions to my eating. And gave me ways to better cope with my emotions, which helped with binge urges. When it came to what I ate I changed the focus from high cal foods, fat foods, good foods, bad foods. To simply how does the food make me feel... Meaning i looked at my health issues acne, stomach issues, fatigue, and focused on what i needed to eat to make these issues better. It allowed me to change up my food to a healthier diet without going on a "diet" because it had nothing to do with weight-loss and wasn't as strict. If i ate food i was trying to avoid it wasn't a big deal but maybe i would get stomach cramps and that was kind of my incentive to not eat shit food. I wanted to feel good. When I changed my perspective it was no longer about my weight it was about my health and i duno, that didnt cause any binge urges. It just worked for me. Everyone has their own way of figuring it out. Sometimes it can take a long time to know what that looks like for you. I was just making the point that going on a diet for the purpose of weight-loss is almost always going to lead right back to where you start. Doesn't mean all diets are evil but with a mental illness the intention behind it matters. If its a diet with the intention of weight-loss or body image, it triggers our illness and leads down the typical road.

If you dont weigh yourself you dont know. Weighing yourself is a trigger to binging. It gives instant anxiety and depression. On the flip side if you loose weight it can give instant gratification which isnt good either. That's a lot of power your giving to a scale. Its better to go off of how you feel. If you feel bloated or heavy then you still know you ate too much but its not measured. It allows you to become more intune with your body instead of allowing a scale to determine your mood for the day. Throw away the scale. In the realm of eating disorders a scale is a hindrance, a problematic behaviour, some even consider it self harm.
Just putting it out there that binge eating is an eating disorder. And eating disorder is a mental illness. Counting calories and dieting will not cure a mental illness. You need mental health care.

Id use insurance to get into a mental health program. Vyvanse isnt a long term solution and a lot of people have problems on it and getting off of it. Its like taking sleeping pills. Sure you can sleep now.... But now your addicted to sleeping pills.

A mental health program will help your BED. Unless you have adhd vyvanse is a short term solution for a long term problem. BED can be cured with mental health treatment. Vyvanse can be very difficult to get off of. It can cause dependency and addiction. Side effects can make your quality of life worse. No one should be on vyvanse without at the same time completing a therapy program. It isn't a miracle drug. It's an aid to recovery at best.
I know a few people who's life got absolutely fucked because of vyvanse. You were right to be weary.

I've seen someone get destroyed by vyvanse. She was an amazing girl but thought it was her only way to recover. Her quality of life went to shit because her side effects were so horrible and she grew a dependency. It's not the only person ive seen get fucked from it but she was especially hard to see because she had so much potential and this stupid drug and her stupid doctor took her life away from her. I havent talked to her in a long time. Hope she figured it out but.... I duno i personally would try everything possible, twice, before going on that stuff but thats me.

Vyvanse is an amphetamine. It is a completely different class of drugs. It's a controlled substance for a reason. Sertraline is a SSRI. It doesn't cause addiction and dependency. The reason vyvanse is working is mostly due to the appetite suppression side effect. SSRIs work to give you a chemical that may be needed. Unless you have adhd vyvanse is simply "working" because the side effect are causing you not to eat. SSRIs may actually solve a problem of chemical imbalance. Vyvanse doesn't actually solve anything if being used just for BED. BED is a symptom of mental health issues. The most successful treatment is therapy. Your doctor wants to use vyvanse as an aid thats fine but it's not the same way antidepressants work.

It's the most important realization you'll ever have. This could be your first step to recovery. Take care of yourself. Dont beat yourself up over binging right now. It's your coping mechanism and its understandable your using it to help you cope with COVID. Once you are better you can use this new found realization to focus on your mental health.

I found this kind of train of thought was the start to my recovery. The fact that it was good food, bad food. Not just food. The fact that I was either dieting or binging on whatever i want... Not just eating. When we're kids we just eat lol. There was a point in our lives where we just ate food. A sandwich, soup, salad, whatever was for dinner we just ate and me personally I was at a healthy weight when I was a kid. Regardless of if what my mom fed me was considered "healthy" or not. I was at a normal weight. Which made me realize it is possible to be at a healthy weight without a diet. I realized I need to bring it back to just food. Re-teach myself how to eat normally. Like human beings are suppose to eat lol. I eat when im hungry, i eat what i like, and i eat whats good for me. It doesn't have to be either , or. All these things can coexist together at the same time.

Unfortunately there are a lot of shitty health care workers out there and she clearly has no idea what shes talking about. First of all the moment a therapist tries to diagnose you, thats a red flag. They are not qualified to do so which is why they are not suppose to. 2nd I am diagnosed BPD I do not abuse drugs or alcohol and I've definitely had symptoms of BPD since 13 years old. 18 is more than old enough to get a proper diagnoses. A therapist more than anyone should know there is a difference between the regular teenage stresses of growing up and a mental illness. Frankly this therapist seems like shes not knowledgable and I would not take any diagnoses seriously from her. If shes a therapist and shes minimizing your experience you should also find a new therapist. Therapists are suppose to validate you and your experience. That's like therapy 101 lol. So unprofessional.

Yes. Truthfully though there is no way I would have been able to accomplish moderation if I wasn't getting proper mental health help. If people are using food as a way to cope with their emotions and aren't learning other skills I think it would be incredibly hard to not binge since at this point its not about the food its just a coping mechanism. Therapy and skills are so important to recovery. Once you've got some good skills under your belt then the food stuff becomes so much easier to figure out.

It takes a long time for our brain to build new pathways. These feelings of shame are just lingering from your disordered eating days. Don't ignore them but also don't over think them. When a judgemental thought comes up just stop and say " I just had a judgemental thought" and move on. Acknowledging the thought but not allowing yourself to dissect it is a helpful skill to help you realize, thoughts aren't facts. Just because your brain says something to you doesn't mean its true. Allowing yourself to hear it, acknowledge it, but move forward can help separate yourself from whats true and whats simply just a thought. Another skill you can use is to check the facts. If your brain says "you have no will power for ordering out". Ask yourself "is this true". Well, no its not. I've been binge free for 8 months, ive done very well. Eating a few things does not mean im relapsing. It means im eating normally. Validating yourself like this can also help those little thoughts quiet down. The hardest part of BED is trying to figure out what normal eating looks like and normal eating means having things you enjoy. Especially on your birthday. Thats as normal as it gets lol. Enjoy yourself. Allow yourself to eat and just try to remind yourself of all your progress and eating some yummy food around your birthday is part of that progress.

Some people are just different. Alcoholics wonder how people can have a few drinks and then go home. Drug addicts wonder how someone could do drugs a few times and then decide to stop. Our drug of choice was food. All these addictions surround mental illness and not everyone has a mental illness. Though it's alot harder to wrap your head around food because everyone eats food not everyone suffers from mental health issues and at the core of it BED is a mental health issue. That's why some people just see it as food. They haven't connected food to their mental health. Just like we don't connect drinking to our mental health but others do. I think eventually though, it will start to normalize. Im 11 months in and though i still have thoughts like you food really is consuming less of my time than it used to.

Will it get worse, stay the same, is it dependant on flares 2. Is there a medicine that helps with this?

All the kids do activities, stated clearly in her moms post. You cant fault one kid because they accomplished a high level in a sport. Chances are the other kids tried gymnastics too and didnt like it or are maybe still involved just not at graces level. I was the one in my family who reached a high level in a sport. Training almost everyday and travelling a lot. My brother was put into ALOT of activities as a kid too but he decided to drop them all. Am I or my parents suppose to be punished for my brothers uninterest in sports because now they spend a lot of money and time on me? Uh no because they gave him the exact same opportunity as me and he as an individual decided not to peruse it. I am sure if one of graces siblings reached elite level they would find a way to pay for them too. You have no idea what's going on in this family other than what graces mom has said which is they all do activities. Maybe the other kids hate competition, maybe they're more creative or enjoy maths more. Maybe theyre drama students or online gamers You have no fucking idea so giving us your assumptions makes you look like an ass to be frank.

Youre projecting your childhood issues onto this family which could be the furthest thing from how any of these siblings actually feel. Graces moms twitter was probably specifically created for graces career. When youre in the spotlight like this there are certain requirements that have to be done and its possible that her mom created the account so she could control the narrative about grace on social media, for all we know its a requirement at that high of a level. You have no idea so dont speculate. Its possible she has a private account with just her family that she posts about all the other kids. You dont know so dont speculate. You also have no idea what these other kids are into. Grace enjoyed gymnastics and accomplished a high level chances are the other kids tried it too and are either doing it but at a low level or tried it and didnt enjoy it. You dont know so dont speculate. For all we know her siblings are more artistic. Maybe theyre in drama club and they really enjoy that so the parents attend a bunch of play to support that child and thats what that child wants. Just because it doesnt take up 6 days a week, tons of money, and travel, doesnt mean that kid isnt absolutely happy that they are doing what they love in drama club and their parents support them by coming to their plays. You dont know so dont speculate. Maybe another child is a huge gamer. Hates sports. Just wants video games to play with all day. Thats what they enjoy and thats all they ask for and they are provided with that. You dont know so dont speculate. Maybe because of graces elite status these kids get opportunities they never would have ( going to other countries to watch her). Maybe they are happy that grace is at this level because they get a chance to travel and do cool things. You dont know so dont speculate. I was in a very similar situation as grace. My family spent a lot of time and money on me because i was an elite in my sport. They gave my sibling ALL the same opportunities as me in sports but they didnt like it. They liked to draw and play video games and they were happy with that life. I shouldnt have been punished because my sibling didnt want to be an elite athlete and my parents shouldn't feel bad because they are giving what my sibling wants. They just want video games and drawing tools. Well he got it. What are they suppose to do? Force him into a sport so we have equal schedules and budgets? It's ridiculous. You dont know so dont speculate!
Its ridiculous to express concern over something that could not be happening your painting a picture with your "concern" to a family that is clearly working hard for all of their kids.

WRITING.TITLE: Okay... Starting to understand the Nicole hate
WRITING.TEXT: I've been defending Nicole in this sub not because I like her but because I thought the hate was extreme. I was saying not liking her personality or gameplay is one thing but the obsessive high level of hate was crazy. Now I'm certainly still not at that level of hate for her BUT catching up on the live feeds from this week and this girl really is such a hater. Like I think in this case, hate is breeding hate. It's one thing to be mad at ppl for a game move but she's taking it to a level of ridiculousness. Her comments about Tyler and Christmas are over the top and unwarranted. She takes it so personally, it's insane. Questioning his AFP win? Like wtf is that? Why is that necessary? I think when you're hateful like that you cant be surprised when you get hate back and though I feel bad for anyone on this show because social media is cruel, she really has done it to herself. I'm done defending her. She just can't stop talking shit, shes got hate in her heart and it is not a good look. Hope she gets the help she needs because this obsessive behavior is seriously troubling. Edit: I want to point out that I am mostly talking about Nicole's private moments. Her talking to the mic or camera while alone. Not her group talks because everyone talks shit so whos to say what they really believe but her private moments talking into the mic where shes just so clearly filled with disdain and hate. Moments that don't require strategy, it's just her own thoughts. This is what's alarming me because those are obviously what shes truly thinking in the moment and it's over the top. I haven't heard many ppl speak like that privately but we've heard it ALOT from Nicole and that's what's started to open my eyes to her true character. I honestly feel for Nicole. I'm saying im understanding the hate not that I hate her but she needs help. She turns everyone that doesn't act her way into an enemy and that is not healthy behavior.

I didnt watch nicoles past seasons so i didnt know her. With janelle I did think she was obsessed but it wasnt like janelle wasnt talking about her either so even though Nicole was overboard i could see why she and janelle had issues and could understand why she was acting the way she waseven though I agree it was a lot. With Tyler hes been nothing but nice to Nicole personally. Yes he tried to get her out but that was strictly game move. Hes always been nice to her and didnt talk shit personally about her to others. Hes a nice decent guy and she knows that so for her to be calling him a joke, and attacking him personally is WAY overboard considering hes been nothing but nice and respectful to her. That why ppl are upset. Janelle throws shade. Thats Janelle's character. Y'all are blind if you think Nicole was solo in the shade throwing but Tyler didnt do anything personally to Nicole to warrant such hate from her and for that matter either did Christmas. Instead of just being sad because you were targeted as a player she turns hateful and attacks ppls personal character who dont deserve it. That's what made me realized the hype is real. I could find some understanding in the Janelle issue I cant with the Tyler.

We see everyone equally on the live feeds. Everyone talks shit. That's how you build trust in that house. By not liking the same ppl. I'm specifically talking about the moments shes by herself talking to the camera saying hateful personal things. There's no reason for that. Theres no strategy to that. Thats showing her true colours. Thats what Nicole thinks and it's not pretty. Ive never heard Tyler talk to the camera and call someone "a joke". In those private moments you can see the uncalled for hate. That's what's alarming me. In Codys private moments hes talking about houseguests from a game stand point. Hes telling us he feels bad but hes saying maybe he doesnt trust them. Hes not calling them disgusting. Theres a big difference and its pretty prevalent when we see these private moments.

Yeah but they can also orchestrate a whole persona on social media that isn't them at all. I agree the house is stressful and brings out the worst in people BUT social media is the last place to go to see someone's real character lmao. You can't hide it when you're being watched 24/7 and even though the house amphiphiles things you can see ppls real characters because they can't fake a persona 24/7. Everyone in that house is dealing with stress. Tyler got depressed and anxious, Christmas gets manic, Nicole A got anxious. We see the effects of the house on everyone but it doesn't make everyone hateful. If stress makes her a hateful person that is something she should absolutely address.
shes turning her insecurities outward. Blaming and condemning others for her own issues. At the very least it's not cool lol.

Nicole shit-talking Tyler alone isn't strategy lol. She's sitting in a bathroom stewing to herself about how much she hates him and putting him down. It's not strategy if no ones around to hear it lmao. I agree it was a bad move on Tyler's part but that's not what I'm talking about in this discussion.

I think it's overkill for people to legitimately hate her lmao. They don't even know her however, I am understanding it a little more AND I do think if she puts hate like that out into the universe it makes sense to me that it's coming back to her. The HOH letter to me really showed how many cognitive distortions she has. Which is unfortunate. She said shell need therapy after this and I think that's exactly what she needs. She's got some looking inward to do I think lol.

This letter reading really proved the kind of cognitive distortions she sees the world with. I don't mean it with malice because I have lots of experience with mental health care but she does need a good therapist to help her realize her problematic thinking patterns. She's got a lot of work to do on herself and I hope she'll take the opportunity to look inward and not project the backlash onto others like Tyler or Janelle because ultimately it's her behaviours that lead to it.

Well, I'm not talking about past people lol. I haven't watched every season of BB so I'm going off of my personal experience with the show and this is my opinion. Also just because others have done it doesn't make it okay for others to do it lol. That's like saying well... Jackson said racist and sexist things and he won so racism and sexism are fine from other houseguests... Like.. nope still not fine lol

Pretty sure I said I did not hate Nicole more than once. I said I was starting to understand it. I agree the house is hard however, we do see 20 other house guests in the same situation that don't resort to hate when they are stressed. I think if someone's default reaction to stress is to turn it outwards to other people it makes sense they are going to receive some hate right back. Hate breeds hate and though I do not hate her because I don't know her and mentioned pretty clearly I think the hate online is excessive it's easy to see why people react the way they do. They feel her hate is unwarranted and mostly unprovoked by respectful house guests. Everyone is facing stressors in there and though everyone is entitled to handle stress in their own way turning it outward onto others as Nicole does is unhealthy and obviously unlikeable. This is a forum for player discussion and I don't think I have displayed any unhealthy behavior in discussing a player. If you see my comments I've been pretty respectful of Nicole and haven't said anything that isn't true.

Yeah thats a shame really. I think she sees herself as a victim and when you dont take responsibility for your own behaviours that's when you see no growth. Lets hope as she gets older and wiser this becomes more apparent to her

She absolutely meets a lot of criteria. She certainly has a lot of distortions common to BPD or even NPD but of course alot of things can look like this. Even an anxiety disorder so yeah its hard to speculate but what I can see for sure are cognitive distortions and negative core beliefs that could certainly be addressed in a therapy program. Nicole if youre reading this DBT and CBT are great therapy programs... Lol... Just in case.

Lol. Just because you don't understand it doesn't mean you have to put it down. It's human behaviour. This show was meant to be a social experiment to test and watch human behaviour. She's showing pretty clear problematic thinking patterns. Would you rather me just call her a bitch? Lol. I rather show so empathy. I can see she has some problematic thinking problems that's leading her to this kind of behaviour. I choose not to call her a bitch like everyone else because it doesn't actually say anything its just a put down. By acknowledging the cause of her behaviour maybe we can humanize her a bit and instead of her being just a villain we can see her as someone who just needs some help and guidance. Personally I think that's a lot less cringy than me just throwing some random mean label on her... But if you don't like the comment luckily you can scroll on by.

Absolutely. Like when Christmas told Davonne not to get upset cause its not personal, thats absurd lol. Of course they are going to be upset if they are targeted. Not only do you want to win but youll feel personally attacked just from a human point of view. No one wants to feel like the one left out, but.... There is a difference between being upset about a situation and what she does which is turn hateful. Her initial emotion is likely sadness. Shes hurt but she seems to turn that into anger and that's not a great way to deal with those emotions. She gets very personal, and mean, and her level of disdain doesnt actually fit the situation thats happening. Everyone reacts differently to stress and she obviously turns it outwards to other ppl but she needs to realize if thats how shes deciding to handle it, its going to bite her in the ass because shes going to be labeled a mean girl. Everyone in that house has the right to get mad about it I am just not a fan of how hateful she is to these ppl in her personal moments especially because everyone in the house has been really respectful to her. She has said some very personally things about them that I feel was over the line. Everyone in there is in the same situation and though everyone handles things differently i do feel like theres been a stark contrast with how she chooses to handle stress and that's where the fans hate is coming from.

Its really awful when you meet someone you are a fan of and they dont meet your expectations. Its understandable you felt disappointed. It also takes a lot of courage to go up to someone like that so when they kind of brush it off as a bother I bet that's hurtful. It sucks that happened to you. Thats why they say dont meet your heros hahaha. Not that she was a hero but I think we can see from her behaviour on the show she isn't very aware of others feelings. Shes pretty self involved so just know that, thats on her, and reflects poorly on her not on you. Fans like you are why she has the life she does so its ashame she choose not to be appreciative that day.

WRITING.TITLE: After months of recovery overeating again on Thanksgiving proved to me BED was self harm.
WRITING.TEXT: I've been in recovery almost a year now and though I've had a few slip ups I haven't binged to the point I used to. Today is Canadian Thanksgiving and I decided to let myself enjoy like everyone else does. I didn't binge because I was in complete control of what I was eating but I did eat more than I normally do and a food that I have not eaten in a very long time. I am uncomfortably bloated, Im dehydrated, I have a headache, I feel sick, I feel anxious, I feel down, and I can't find a comfortable position to lay or sit in. Im now trying to go to sleep with all of this discomfort wondering how the hell I did this to myself every single day for years. It made me realize that at the heart of this disorder it is absolutely a self harm tactic. There is no other way to describe how I put myself through this torture everyday like it was normal other than some part of me wanted to be in pain. People who wonder how "normal" people dont binge on food. How they can control portions and stop when their full. It's because of this. Its because over eating makes ppl feel sick. Those that don't have mental health issue don't like to feel sick so they stop. If food is a form of self harm for us it makes sense we continue to keep going even though we know its going to cause us pain. Maybe we do it because it causes us pain. It sucks man. Focus on the mental health part. Food really doesnt control my life and though i sometimes still have days like this where I over eat I ALWAYS regret it and it reminds me why food isnt as amazing as I once thought it was. I ate a medium pizza tonight and though I used to eat ALOT more on my binges this was way too much for me tonight. I genuinely enjoy my homemade chicken souvlaki more than I did this pizza and maybe that's how I know im in recovery lol.

You absolutely dont have to be overweight. The criteria is around behaviour and although alot of ppl will be overweight it isnt a requirement to be diagnosed. We used to binge together and she always got more food. Somehow i ended up at 300lbs and she was 130. Just totally different metabolisms.

Yup. This is EXACTLY my problem right now. I had bad cystic acne. Changed my diet and cleared up my skin but for 1 week every fucking month im dealing with acne all over again. I feel like as soon as my hormonal acne finally heels and my skin is starting to look really good its period time again and the cycle restarts. Yes def HS. This looks exactly like mine. HS can progress. I only had in on my lower half until i was late 20s. I started eating worse and gaining weight and all of a sudden i went from a stage 1 to a stage 3. It progressed to my boobs,stomach, and underarms. After years of that ive finally found my triggers and im back down to a stage 1 and have minimal flares up top again. If your noticing a progression maybe look at whats changed in your lifestyle. See if there is a culprit food, weight gain, stress, started smoking, anything that could be a link to the progression.

WRITING.TITLE: 12 months of recovery, almost 90lbs down, all that success to still be called fat by a total stranger.
WRITING.TEXT: These are the days when all this body positive, confident in your own body stuff just seems like total bullshit. How am I suppose to be confident when its proven ppl just see me as a fat person. It's like the automatic insult is to call me fat and they say it like "how dare you say anything to me you're fat". I feel like a second class citizen and what hurts the most is how far ive come just to have the same insult hurled at me a year later and 90lbs down. I gained weight because i was sick. I was sick with this, i was sick with other mental illnesses, and I was sick with a chronic health condition. This along with medicine skyrocketed my weight to 300lbs in just a few years. Ive been in recovery coming up a year now. Im at 213lbs now and though yes, i understand that is still obese. It is FAR away from where I was. I was honestly really starting to build confidence in myself. Clothes are actually falling off of me. I can see my waist again. I can actually take a decent selfie again lol and I was starting to literally walk with my head held high again. Than this woman reminds me what I really look like. Just some fat person. She doesn't know how fat I used to be but it doesn't matter cause im still just another fat person. Sad thing is its the 2nd time in the last few months a stranger has called me fat. At least the first person did it unintentionally this one tried to tell me if I dieted and wasnt fat I wouldn't get sick with covid ( she was a real peice of work. So dont even want to get into the covid part of it) but i just thought I am on a healthy fucking diet! Ive lost a ton of weight! Its infuriating she knows nothing about me and says that because its the most obvious insult she can think of. It makes me so upset that, thats the first place someone goes. Ive worked fucking hard for the last year and people still see me as a lazy, unhealthy, fat person and im honestly really hurt and really sad about it. Makes me want to hide away in my home again like i used to. People are cruel. I just needed to rant because no one else I know as ever been called fat by a stranger so they don't exactly empathize.

That's simply not true. It's pretty common knowledge now that the mentally ill are far more likely to be victims of violence than be the perpetrators. I live in an area with a ridiculous abundance of mentally ill homeless, and homeless drug addicts. Ive also spent alot of time in mental health hospitals. Not once has anything bad happened to me by being around them. This comment is the epitome of ignorance. Dont know if youve seen whats going on in the states but id bet we'd see violence from a trump supporter before we did from someone with a mental illness. I am actually pretty confident id be more likely to be attacked as a liberal in that crowd than as a person walking down the street passing a mentally ill person.

I get what you are saying but being in my 30s having gone through being sexual harassed and abused multiple times by men in my life I can say it's probably coming from a place of love and concern because with my history I would probably be the same way with my child. Who knows maybe your mom had some bad experiences too. In a perfect world it would be nice for women to be able to wear what ever they want and be treated like equals but I am very sorry to say that still isnt the case and even if your mom brought you and your brother up with these values it doesnt mean everyone else was brought up with the same values. I think it is overboard to not let you wear shorts in the house but the point I am trying to make is to maybe give your mom a bit of a break because you don't quite know what's leading to her decision. Honestly, I think the best way to sort this out is sit down and have a real conversation about it. Don't come in attacking but just sit down and ask. "I would really like to know your reasoning behind thinking woman shouldn't wear shorts in their own homes because I don't really understand it but would love to understand your perspective on it".

One problem us humans have is to project our emotions onto animals. We believe they feel the way we do but it's just not true. We have absolutely no way of knowing how a dog thinks or what it feels so even though you are upset and expect your other dog to be upset to I would try to let that go because they are a different species than us and will not compute this in the same way we do. Let the dog be a dog. Whatever grieving or not grieving may look like that's what comes natural to them and that's okay. I had 4 cats at one time and none of them bated an eye when one would pass away. Maybe it really affected them and we didn't know but it kind of just is what it is. Some dogs may be more expressive than others or have a better understanding than others and thats why you see stories of dogs grieving but thats not going to be true for all dogs.
You could have said that in a nicer way. The person is obviously going through a loss and just cares.
