WRITING.TITLE: YSK: Visine eye drops are not lubricating eye drops and if used regularly are actually bad for your eyes.
WRITING.TEXT: Why YSK: Visine could be causing you more harm than good by temporarily fixing the issue of red eyes without actually addressing the underlining problems. Visine is, fundamentally, a decongestant. Redness in your eyes can be caused by swollen and congested blood vessels; these blood vessels, when irritated, become #160;filled with blood and get backed up. Visine solves the problem by causing the affected blood vessels to artificially constrict. The active ingredients in Visine cause blood vessels to physically shrink. This accomplishes the immediate goal of lessening the eye #8217;s redness, however, as the medication eventually wears off, a phenomenon known to eye doctors as #8220;rebound redness #8221; may occur, which makes the initial problem that much worse. In fact, over a prolonged period of continuous Visine usage, the rebound redness may actually become the default condition of the patient #8217;s eyes. It #8217;s true: Visine can permanently imprint on your eyes the very condition that it was originally intended to improve. This is because Visine makes a basic mistake: it temporarily addresses the patient #8217;s symptom (redness) without adequately solving the underlying cause (which may vary). And it can be even worse for contact lens wearers, because Visine can also dilate a patient #8217;s pupils when used too much, too often. Contact lens wearers may become increasingly sensitive to light and experience blurry vision. If you are looking for dry eye relief be sure to look for "Artificial Tears" not "Red Eye Treatment". Artificial tears are used to lubricate the eye where red eye treatment just constrict the blood vessels. Warm compress on the eyes, lid washes, and fish oil supplements are even better ways to address and possibly solve red, itchy eyes without causing harm. *I've worked in the eye care industry for 10 years and it's very common for people to think Visine is just a regular eyedrop because their marketing has been very successful but has lacked the proper education on how the drop actually works. Citation: [America Academy of Opthalmology. ](https://www.aao.org/eye-health/treatments/redness-relieving-eye-drops)

That's a good question! It's common for our eyes to create an abundance of tears when our eyes are irritated so even though the problem may feel like you have too much lubrication the cause is often due to the opposite. One of the most common causes of watery eyes are dryness. Your eyes are creating an overload of tears because your eyes arent lubricated properly. In this case I would start using an artificial tear regularly to try to build up that moisture again. I am in Canada so I don't know if we have the same brands but Refresh and Systane are the ones I enjoy using. Another common issue with watery eyes are your glands may be blocked. This can happen really easily from our skin oils or makeup. When the glands are blocked they aren't able to lubricate our eyes properly. This typically causes dry eye and may even cause other issues likes styes and bacteria which will cause watery eyes too. There are a few things you can do to make sure your glands are working as they should. 1) use a warm compress. This will help open up the glands so they can work properly. 2) Make sure to wash your face at night to remove those oils, you can buy a lid cleaner so you can clean properly around the lash line and ensure nothing is getting trapped 3) Get an artificial tear to help relieve the symptom of dry eyes while you are working on the cause of it. 4)Taking fish oil supplements are a natural way to help combat dry eyes. The third thing could be allergies. Allergies often cause watery, itchy eyes. Its best to try to figure out your allergy and avoid it but if that's not an option using allergy drops can help temporarily but again they are a drop that you have to be cautious using. Best to try a regular artificial tear first and the steps above to see if that relives some issues. If its allergies taking a regular antihistamine may help as well. Hope that helps!

Lol. I would say you can keep it around for an "emergency" type situation. Like "oh no i have a job interview and my eyes are bloodshot" or "omg I have wedding pictures and my eyes are bloodshot" lol but other than that I would advise you dont use them and try the other things I've listed below for the health of your eyes.
Rohto redness reliving drops will be the same deal and should be used sparingly. They have similar ingredients plus menthol which may feel good but can be quite irriatating to the eye.

It depends on the cause of the redness. If you have chronic redness you should really see an optometrist because there could be an underlying health issue there. Not saying there is but there are potential serious diseases and conditions that can cause chronic red eye. Until then I would definitely try using an artifical tear regularly. I would also try a warm compress regularly until you feel some relief happening. They sell bean bag masks on amazon that are great for that. Making sure you wash your lids and lash line well. Wash your lids with either a lid wash or a gentle baby shampoo. Taking fish oil supplements are great for eye health, so is eating food rich in vitamin A. Trying to figure out if anything triggers the red eye to work out if it could be an allergy. Maybe keep notes of everytime you notice the red eye is worse and write down what you did before, what you handled, what you ate, what the allergy report is for the day, etc. to see if there is a pattern. Most importantly if you are a regular user of redness eyedrops stop because its probably making it worse ESP if you have a condition thats causing it the eyedrops could cause damage.

Yeah Visine is especially not good for contact lens wearers but I will point out that even though contact lens solution ultimately goes in your eye it is not designed to hydrate your eye and can cause more harm than good even if it feels good. Contact lens solutions are very good at what they do, which is to disinfect and store your lenses. Their function is to kill microbes on your lenses. They are therefore toxic to living cells #8211; including your own. The vast majority are preserved with chemicals that are also toxic to eyes #8211; sometimes causing prolonged inflammation. The temptation may be strong to add a little moisture by squeezing in a drop of storage solution directly into your eye while wearing your lens #8230; BUT avoid this strategy if you want to continue to be able to wear your lenses long term. If your eyes feel dry or uncomfortable, then you should look at #160;treating the dryness rather than using your solution to refresh the lenses. Getting an artifical tear eye drop is the safest and easiest way to avoid dryness. It will actually help solve the problem rather than just the symptoms. They now have eye drops specifically for if you are wearing contact lenses which you can use if you need extra moisture while they are on.

Gas permeable contact lenses are certainly harder on eyes than the regular soft lenses. There are a few reasons you may have to wear gas permeable but I know soft contacts have come a long way in regards to rx range so maybe it's worth asking your doctor if they have anything available for you yet in a soft contact ( if rx range was the issue) Besides that I would certainly follow all the recommendations I said previously: using an artifical tear regularly. Best before you put them on and after you take them off. Using a warm compress maybe once or twice a week can ensure your glands are working at their best. Taking fish oil supplements are a way to naturally increase moisture in your eye so that is an easy add on that could help with some dry eye symptoms. Most importantly for you since you have these types of contacts and have symptoms of dry eye I would make sure you wear eye protection outside. Work googles will be really helpful to keep irritants like dust, debris, and irritation from the wind out of your eyes. A lot of ppl who work outdoors or in dirty dusty environments find they have chronic dry/red eyes and it's because there are allow of things that can get into the eyes with those environments.

The THC inside of cannabis decreases your blood pressure. This ultimately leads to the expansion of our blood vessels to allow more blood to flow around our body. In the case of eyes, it means that our ocular capillaries are dilated so that they can take in more blood. These expanded blood vessels make the white of the eye appear red, hence the effect. Visine is actually used exactly to solve this problem by constricting those blood vessels back down but if you are a regular marijuana user and use visine regularly its not great for eye health. If im being honest your best bet is not to smoke weed when you need to be around ppl without red eyes lol. The redness in your eyes from smoking isnt causing any issues but it's obviously athestically not a great look. If you can avoid smoking during these times thats ideal or use Visene sparingly. If not you can try a cold compress. Cold can help shrink those blood vessels as well.

I linked a great article below that explains the pros and cons of this eyedrop well. In short its better than Visine but still only address red eye and not the cause of red eye so though its safer to use more frequently than Visine ultimately you should try to treat the cause of the red eye rather than the symptom of eye redness for long term success. [lumify eye drops](https://www.shape.com/lifestyle/beauty-style/lumify-eye-drops)

Contact lenses can be a cause of dry eye so its very important to take care of your eyes so you are able to continue to wear contact lenses. If you get chronic dry eyes contact lenses arent going to be comfortable anymore. Most important is to use contact lenses as instructed. If it says only wear for 8 hours and then throw out then do that. If you can wear for 8 hours a day for 2 weeks then do that. Any "abuse" of contact lenses can lead to chronic dry eye issues and maybe other infections/issues. Make sure your case is always clean and you are always using fresh contact lens solution to clean them. If you feel symptoms of dry eye you can use an artificial tear before and after you have them in. They do also make drops specifically for when you have contacts in if you need. Fish oil supplements will help keep your eyes healthy and helps with moisture. There are also certain brands of contacts that are better than others when it comes to dry eye. Acuvue Oasys line of contacts is quite good for dry eyes.

The point of this post was to make ppl aware that Visine is not a regular eye drop. It has one purpose and that is to reduce red eye on a seldom bases. Visine doesn't clearly state the difference between a red eye reducer and an artificial tear in ads which is why there is a misconception that Visine is probably good for dry eyes. Many ppl think all eye drops are interchangeable so I was educating that is not the case. Of course Visene is trying to sell Visine lol but I wanted to let ppl know that if they didn't know the difference its not their fault since they don't exactly do a good job of explaining how their product works. If they could just make it more obvious whether on their box or in their ads that it does not treat dry eyes then ppl wouldn't be misusing it as much.

When you are working on a computer you actually blink less which causes strain and dryness. With computer use there is a 20-20-20 rule. Every 20 minutes look up from your screen, look at something 20 ft away for 20 seconds. This is kind of like an eye reset that can help prevent fatigue. Making sure your computer screen is at a proper distance is important as well. The blue light filter glasses will be helpful. You can also change your screen settings to reduce blue light. Its on most computers now in display settings or you can download free programs that will add a tint to your screen to help. I stare at a screen as well and my favourite thing to do for eye care is a warm compress. Before or after work it helps open up the glands of your lid which aids with lubrication. I use a bean bag type eye mask off of amazon that you just microwave. After 5-10 mins its instant relief. For long term eye health fish oil supplements can help dry eye naturally.

If it is classic visine to relive redness its likely not good to be using regularly especially after correction surgery. Look for the ingredients Tetrahydrozoline or Naphazoline.
